value: The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic, in its Monetary Policy meeting of January 2012, decided to keep its Monetary Policy Rate unchanged at 6.75% per annum. At the same time, it decided to leave the Lombard Interest Rate unchanged at 9.0% per annum.

The decision regarding the reference rate is based on the fact that no deviations are foreseen for the inflation projection with respect to the target and for the prospects of the main determinants of inflation. For 2012, the Monetary Board, under the new explicit inflation targeting (EMI) scheme, approved a goal of 5.5% <U+00B1> 1% for this indicator. In December 2011, monthly inflation was 0.1%, while the year-on-year rate reached 7.8%. In addition, the interannual core inflation rose to 5.2% at the end of the year.

In the external context, both the IMF and the Consensus Forecast maintain their perspectives of moderation in the growth of the world economy. The projections suggest that the United States would continue its path of incipient recovery, while Europe could be entering recession in 2012. The solution of economic policy in the eurozone seems to confront a dilemma between fiscal austerity and economic growth, which makes it difficult to correct the process of debt crisis and fiscal sustainability of that monetary union, as discussed at the recent World Economic Forum in Davos. However, it is important to note that the European Union recently approved a fiscal rule that would allow the sustainability of public accounts in the long term.

On the other hand, forecasts show that emerging economies would be slowing down while international financial conditions remain restricted. In that sense, China would be growing below the average of recent years, while the growth forecasts for Latin America are corrected to the downside. The prices of raw materials remain high amid geopolitical tensions in the Middle East.

In the domestic sphere, private credit, economic activity and inflation evolve in accordance with the projections of the recent Monetary Policy Report. Credit to the private sector continues to expand at a rate close to projected nominal GDP, indicating that domestic demand preserves its growth. At the same time, the forecasts point to a convergence of interannual inflation to the target during the first quarter of 2012, which indicates that even in the middle of an electoral cycle, price stability and the continuity of macroeconomic policies would be maintained, creating a environment of certainty that facilitates the decision making of private economic agents.

The Central Bank will continue to monitor the evolution of the global and domestic economy in order to react in a timely manner to risks regarding price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.

The Monetary Board, through the second resolution of December 20, 2012, decided to modify the interest rate corridor, formed by the rates of short-term remunerated deposits (overnight) and Lombarda, with which it had operated its policy during the last years. In this sense, it established that from now on the Monetary Policy Interest Rate of the Central Bank (TPM) will be exclusively a Reference Rate of the 1-Day Liquidity Operations performed by the institution, instead of the rate of paid deposits of the Central Bank. short term, which had fulfilled that role since 2005.In the external context, economic activity in the United States of America recorded a slight contraction of 0.1% in the fourth quarter of 2012, closing the year at 2.2%. For 2013, an expansion of 2.0% is expected according to the Economic Consensus (Consensus Forecast). The fiscal risks of the United States have moderated temporarily, while in the Euro Zone recessive conditions persist, estimating a fall of 0.4% by the end of 2012. Additionally, there is a loss of dynamism in important countries in the area, particularly Germany and France. On the other hand, the Economic Consensus predicts that Latin America's growth would be 2.7% in 2012. In most of the countries of the region, monetary policy maintains a neutral stance. International financial conditions have improved relatively and prices of primary goods remain above their historical levels. In the domestic sphere, production and domestic demand behave as predicted in the most recent Monetary Policy Report. Economic activity grew in 2012 at around 4.0%, higher than the average for Latin America. This growth indicates a moderate recovery in the second half of the year, but staying below its long-term trend. During this year, production will remain below its potential, recovering its path from next year, supported by an improvement in private consumption and investment, as total credit is recovered and economic activity is boosted.Regarding the possible impact on domestic prices, stemming from the implementation of the fiscal reform, the Central Bank estimates that its effect would have a transitory and one-off nature, so that inflation would remain around the target of this year.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation in order to react timely to risks on price stability and good functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting in January 2014, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic decided to maintain the reference rate at 6.25% per annum.

The decision regarding the monetary policy rate took into account the balance of risks around the inflation projections, as well as market expectations. The year-on-year inflation rate closed at 3.88% in December, decreasing for the fourth consecutive month. This result was slightly below the lower limit of the target range of 5.0% <U+00B1> 1.0%. Additionally, the interannual core inflation, which is associated with inflationary pressures of monetary origin, fell to 4.42%, closing below the central value of the target.

In the external context, the conditions of the world economy are characterized by a process of gradual recovery, based on a better performance of the developed countries, particularly the United States of America (USA), which grew 3.2% in the last quarter of 2013 and 1.9% throughout the year, reducing the unemployment rate from 7.9% in December 2012 to 6.7% in December 2013. According to Consensus Forecast, the US economy would grow 2.8% in 2014, while the Euro Zone would expand by 1.0%, leaving behind the recessive stage of the economic cycle.

The gradual reduction of the monetary stimulus by the Federal Reserve (FED), reducing its monthly purchases of financial assets to inject liquidity in US $ 20,000 million, would be restricting international financial conditions and provoking capital returns to the industrialized economies. In this context, some of the larger emerging economies such as Argentina, Brazil, India, Turkey and South Africa, mostly exporters of commodities, have experienced exchange rate pressures, which has led their central banks to tighten monetary policy stance through increases in interest rates, liquidity restrictions and interventions in the foreign exchange market, to face possible effects on inflation.

It is important to point out that given the greater growth of production and employment in the US, there is a consensus among the governors of the FED that there will be no increases in the reference rate of monetary policy, at least until 2015. In that sense, the The gradual withdrawal of the monetary stimulus and the temporary volatility it has caused in the international capital markets, would have minimal effects on the financial and exchange markets of the smaller economies, with good macroeconomic fundamentals and without active participation in the global financial markets, as it is the case of the Dominican Republic. However, the greater dynamism in the economic activity of the United States, the country's main trading partner, would have a positive impact on Dominican economic growth, through exports and the flow of remittances, which would increase the supply of foreign currency in the country. Dominican exchange market, facilitating the maintenance of the relative stability of the exchange rate.

Additionally, economic activity and domestic demand show remarkable dynamism as of the fourth quarter of 2013, growing by 7.2%, driven during this period by exports, investment and private consumption. Credit to the private sector in national currency continues to expand at a rate above the nominal product, while improving prospects for activities related to foreign trade. In this sense, it is expected that in this year the current account deficit of the balance of payments would continue to be corrected, which together with the strengthening of public finances, would contribute to improving the macroeconomic performance of the Dominican Republic and its perception of country risk.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation in order to take the necessary measures against risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.

At its monetary policy meeting in January 2015, the Central Bank decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate (MPR) unchanged at 6.25% per annum, thus continuing with the neutral position it has maintained since August 2013.

The decision on the benchmark interest rate was adopted after a thorough analysis of the risk balance around inflation projections, as well as the state of the economy based on its main indicators, market expectations and the international environment relevant. Last December, the year-on-year rate of inflation closed at 1.58%, while core inflation, related to the monetary conditions of the economy, was 2.97%. The inflation target from 2015 is 4.0% <U+00B1> 1%, according to the Monetary Program under the Inflation Targets, published at the end of last year. In the policy horizon, projections suggest that inflation would converge to the medium-term goal, while the economy would continue to grow close to its potential.

In the international environment, the outlook for the growth of the world economy for 2015 remains moderate due to the projected trajectory for the Euro Zone, Japan and other industrialized economies. The United States of America shows a flattering outlook regarding the rate of expansion of its production due to the good performance of investment and private consumption. However, at its first monetary policy meeting in 2015, the Federal Reserve Bank maintained its MPR in the 0% -0.25% range, indicating that it would leave it at least until the third quarter of the year. In terms of emerging economies, Consensus Forecast has adjusted the growth projections for Asia and Latin America to 4.7% and 1.1%, respectively.

On the other hand, the downward trend in the prices of the main primary goods (commodities), particularly fuels and industrial metals, continues, while international financial conditions have become more restrictive for emerging economies. As a result of the application of more expansive monetary policies in the Euro Zone, Japan and other economies with problems of economic growth, the US dollar has tended to appreciate worldwide and long-term interest rates in industrialized countries have been reduced. .

In the domestic sphere, economic activity grew 7.1% in 2014 and it is expected that in 2015 it will continue to register an expansion close to its potential. In January, credit to the private sector in local currency was 15.6% in year-on-year terms, while total credit to the private sector, including foreign currency financing, would close this month with growth above 18.0% over the year. previous. In the fiscal part, adjustments continue and it is expected that by 2015 the Central Government deficit would be 2.4% of GDP. This process of fiscal consolidation would help strengthen the sustainability of the debt, which has improved with the operation of handling liabilities recently made by the Dominican Government with the Venezuelan company PDVSA. Additionally, external accounts will continue to strengthen in the current year and a current account deficit is projected for the end of 2015 in the range of 1.9% -2.1% of GDP. The continuous strengthening of the macroeconomic foundations of the Dominican economy facilitates the maintenance of the relative stability of the exchange rate and a greater accumulation of international reserves.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to implement monetary policy aimed at achieving its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to take the necessary measures against risks to the stability of the economy. prices and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting for the month of January 2016, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.00% per annum.

The decision on the reference rate has been made after an examination of the international environment relevant to the Dominican economy, as well as the domestic context taking into account the balance of risks around inflation projections and market expectations. It was observed that, as of December 2015, the interannual inflation rate reached 2.34%, below the lower limit of the goal established in the Monetary Program. At the same time, core inflation, which reflects the monetary conditions of the economy, amounted to 1.82% last year. Inflation is expected to converge gradually towards the center of the target range of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0% in the policy horizon.

Externally, the most recent World Economic Outlook (WEO) of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) reduced the projections for world growth from 3.6% to 3.4% for 2016, due to the problems of the main emerging economies, particularly the emerging economies. net exporters of primary goods. After the increase of its monetary policy rate (MPR) in the month of December, the Federal Reserve Bank (FED) decided to keep its MPR unchanged in January, faced with greater uncertainty in the international financial markets. The slowdown in China and the recession in several of the leading emerging economies have pushed up the country risk premiums of these economies, while the US dollar has appreciated and the price of oil and stock indicators have declined.

The most recent forecasts of the Consensus Forecast (CFC) highlight that world growth would be led by the expansion of the industrialized countries. In that sense, the United States of America (USA) would register an expansion of 2.4% in 2016 and 2.5% in 2017, while the Euro Zone (ZE) would continue consolidating its recovery with growth rates of 1.7% in 2016 and 2017. Inflation is expected to approach 2.0% in both the US and the ZE, while unemployment continues to fall.

The macroeconomic conditions of emerging economies remain weak. The outlook points to a slight improvement in 2016. Latin America would present a growth of 0.3% in 2016, reaching a recovery in 2017, with an expansion of 2.3%. This result would be influenced by the evolution of Venezuela and Brazil, which would remain in recession until 2016, as well as by the moderation of growth in the net exporting economies of raw materials in the region.

Domestically, economic activity continues to grow above its potential. Preliminary data show a GDP expansion rate of 7.0% in 2015. In the financial sector, private loans in local currency show a year-on-year growth of close to 12%, exceeding nominal product growth.

The external accounts of the Dominican economy continue to improve in an environment of low oil prices and good performance in tourism revenues, remittances and exports from free zones. It is expected that by 2016, the current account deficit will remain around 2.0% of GDP. With regard to fiscal policy, the 2016 Budget contemplates maintaining discipline within the consolidation and sustainability efforts of public accounts. The adequate behavior of external and fiscal accounts in 2016 would facilitate the accumulation of reserves and the relative stability of the foreign exchange market.

The Central Bank confirms its commitment to implement monetary policy aimed at achieving its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to take the necessary measures against possible risks to stability of prices and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting for the month of January 2017, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate (MPR) at 5.50% per annum.

The decision on the benchmark interest rate was adopted after a thorough analysis of the risk balance around inflation projections, as well as the state of the economy based on its main indicators, market expectations and the international environment. relevant. Last December, the year-on-year rate of inflation closed at 1.70%, while core inflation, related to the monetary conditions of the economy, was 1.89%. According to the projections, inflation would converge to the target range of 4% <U+00B1> 1% in the monetary policy horizon.

In the external context, the growth prospects of the world economy are positive, with an estimated rate of expansion of 2.5% in 2016 and 2.8% in 2017, according to Consensus Forecast. This improvement in world economic activity would be influenced by the United States of America (USA), which according to preliminary figures recorded a growth of 1.6% in 2016, having experienced an expansion of 1.9% year-on-year in the last quarter. For the year 2017, a better performance of this economy is expected when projecting a growth of 2.3% associated with the positive expectation of the fiscal stimulus plan that the new government of that country would implement. The greater dynamism of the US, our main trading partner, should be a positive factor for our economy in 2017.

Regarding the Euro Zone (ZE), it is estimated that the real product would expand 1.6% in 2016 and in 2017 it would reach a growth of 1.4%. Inflation in these industrialized economies has maintained a positive trend, gradually approaching the targets set by its central banks. In the case of Latin America, the region would have closed in 2016 with a contraction of -0.6%, to recover in 2017 with a growth of 1.2%, according to estimates of the International Monetary Fund. On the other hand, the international prices of most primary goods show a growing trend so far this year, especially oil, industrial metals and some foods.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity expanded at a rate of 6.6% in 2016, being the highest in the region for the third consecutive year. In the monetary sector, the dynamism in total financial system credit continues to the private sector, both in domestic and foreign currency, growing by 11.9% at the end of 2016, above the expansion of nominal GDP. Public finances during the second semester of 2016 have strengthened, as there has been an improvement in tax revenues and a moderation in public spending, with a primary surplus expected for the end of the year, which would contribute to strengthening the sustainability of the public debt.

In addition, the strengthening of macroeconomic fundamentals was maintained during 2016, when the lowest current account deficit was recorded in the last decade (-1.5% of GDP), influenced by the dynamism of tourism, remittances and national exports. This good performance of the external sector allowed the Gross International Reserves to close the year at historically high levels of US $ 6,047.4 million, equivalent to a coverage of 3.9 months of imports, which gives the Dominican economy greater strength to react to any event adverse and guarantee the relative stability of the foreign exchange market.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to continue conducting monetary policy aimed at achieving its inflation target and maintaining macroeconomic stability, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, In order to adopt the necessary measures in the face of risks regarding price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting in January 2018, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.25% per annum.

This decision was based on an exhaustive analysis of the balance of risks around inflation forecasts, the evolution of the main national macroeconomic indicators, the international environment, market expectations and medium-term projections. Inflation for the month of December 2017 was 0.97%, while year-on-year inflation stood at 4.20%, close to the central value of the target range of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0% established in the Monetary Program. In turn, core inflation, related to monetary conditions, reached 2.36% year-to-year at the end of 2017. Forecasts indicate that inflation would remain within the target range in the 24-month monetary policy horizon.

In the international arena, the world economy experienced a growth of 3.2% in 2017, while for 2018 Consensus Forecast (CFC) estimates an expansion rate of 3.3% for the global economy. In 2017, the behavior of the world economy was driven by the performance of advanced economies, particularly by growth rates of 2.3% in the United States of America (USA) and 2.5% in the Euro Zone (ZE). By 2018, CFC projects that the dynamism of the advanced economies would continue with an expansion of 2.7% in the US and 2.2% in the ZE. On the price side, US inflation was 2.1% in 2017 and that of the EZ of 1.4%, while it is expected that by 2018 in both economies the price growth would be similar to last year.

The recovery continued in Latin America (AL) during 2017, estimating a growth of 1.8% according to Consensus Forescast. By 2018, it is expected that all countries in the region would maintain a positive economic performance, with the sole exception of Venezuela. In that sense, the growth projections of CFC point to an expansion for the region of 2.6% by the end of 2018. In general terms, large economies of Latin America, exporters of commodities, would benefit from the upward trend that is observed in the international prices of primary goods, while at the same time they would be facing favorable international financial conditions in an environment of abundant liquidity worldwide.

In the domestic context, the economy has reacted favorably to monetary easing measures that were implemented as of August 2017. Since that period, the active interest rate has been significantly reduced and loans to the private sector in national currency have grown in about RD $ 55 billion. The growth of credit reached 12.5% ??year-to-year at the end of January, generating a great dynamism in investment and consumption, which boosted the recovery of domestic demand. Indeed, preliminary information from the Monthly Indicator of Economic Activity (IMAE) indicates a growth of 7.4% in the month of December and an accumulated expansion of 4.6% during the year 2017. The outlook for the Dominican economy in 2018 is positive, when projecting a growth of around 5.5% in the Monetary Program, influenced by greater expansion in the US, our main trading partner, and by the dynamism of credit at the domestic level. Macroeconomic models indicate that growth could be even higher at the end of the year, approaching 6.0%.

On the other hand, the external sector continues to record a good performance, closing 2017 with a Current Account deficit of -0.2% of GDP, the lowest in thirteen years. Likewise, the positive result of the global balance of payments allowed an accumulation of international reserves of some US $ 730 million, about 4.4 months of importation. The dynamism of foreign exchange generating activities such as tourism, remittances and foreign investment contributed to this remarkable accumulation of international reserves, while at the same time facilitating the maintenance of the relative stability of the exchange rate.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target and to maintain macroeconomic stability, helping to create the conditions for the economy to grow around its potential. In that sense, it will continue to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to adopt the necessary measures against possible risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
BCRD keeps its monetary policy rate at 5.50% per year

Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic. - At its January 2019 monetary policy meeting, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.50% per annum.

The decision to render the benchmark unchanged is based on a detailed analysis of the risk balance around inflation forecasts, including information from international and domestic macroeconomic indicators, market expectations and medium-term projections. December's monthly inflation was -0.22%, closing the year at 1.17%. Underlying inflation, which isolates the effects of those volatile components, closed the year at 2.47%. The forecasting system indicates that inflation would gradually converge to the target range of 4.0% to 1.0% over the 24-month policy horizon.

Recently, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) published its Global Economic Outlook (WEO) report and highlighted the slowdown in global economic growth, reducing its 2019 projections from 3.7% to 3.5% and 2020 from 3.9% to 3.6%.

On the other hand, Consensus Forecast predicts that the world economy would grow 2.9% during 2019 and 2.8% by 2020. Global expansion of economic activity would continue to be driven by the United States of America, although a moderation in its growth is expected, reaching 2.5% in 2019 and 1.8% by 2020. Consensus Forecast also maintained its moderate growth forecast in the Euro Zone (ZE), with expansions of 1.5% in 2019 and 1.4% in 2020.

It can be seen from the projections of both the IMF and Consensus Forecast, which is seen as more uncertainty on the international stage, which could have an effect on policy decisions in advanced economies. In that regard, at its last meeting, the US Federal Reserve announced that the next monetary policy normalization would follow a more gradual process this year.

In the case of Latin America, the region is projected to grow 1.9% in 2019 and 2.5% in 2020, driven by the dynamism of economies such as the Dominican Republic, Bolivia, Panama, Paraguay, Chile and Peru. However, economic vulnerabilities and socio-political tensions continue in countries such as Venezuela, Argentina and Nicaragua, economies that would remain in recession in 2019.

As for raw materials, after a few months of falls, the price of oil has recovered reaching about US$54 per barrel in January. Recent behavior has been influenced by a drop in both OPEC's oil inventories and production, as well as increased uncertainty in financial markets. Also, according to the International Energy Agency, the price of oil would remain around US$55 a barrel, on average, during 2019.

Domestically, economic activity continues to grow above its potential, in a context of low inflationary pressures. Indeed, real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) expanded by 7.0% during 2018, driven mainly by investment and private consumption. Consistent with economic dynamism, there is an increase in credit to the private sector in national currency by around 11.0% year-on-year in January 2019.

Importantly, the weighted average passive interest rate on multiple banking has increased by about 100 basis points following the July 2018 Monetary Policy Rate increase. This adjustment has made it possible to close the interest rate differential against U.S. rates, helping to avoid risks in macroeconomic stability.

On the fiscal policy side, public spending moderated during 2018, accounting for 5.9% growth in erogations at the end of the year, while revenue expansion reached 12.5% year-on-year, contributing to the process of consolidation of public finances. In the external sector, foreign exchange-generating activities such as tourism, remittances and exports remain in remarkable dynamism, contributing to the fact that the current account deficit in the balance of payments will close the year at around -1.4% of GDP, despite a higher oil bill. The good performance of the external sector has facilitated the accumulation of international reserves in addition to contributing to the relative stability of the exchange rate.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic remains attentive to the evolution of the U.S. monetary policy normalization, as well as the performance of the dollar in the international market and the price of oil globally, being prepared to react in a timely manner to any factor that may cause inflationary diversions. In this regard, the issuing body reaffirms its commitment to driving monetary policy towards the achievement of its inflation target and the smooth functioning of the financial and payment systems, thus contributing to the maintenance of macroeconomic stability.
BCRD maintains its monetary policy rate at 4.50% per year
At its January 2020 monetary policy meeting, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 4.50% per annum.

The benchmark decision is based on detailed risk balance analysis for inflation forecasts, including international and domestic macroeconomic indicators, market expectations and medium-term projections. December's monthly inflation was 0.20%, while year-on-year inflation at the end of 2019 stood at 3.66%, below the focus of the target of 4.0% to 1.0%. Underlying inflation, reflecting monetary conditions, stood at 2.25% in December. Going forward, both the inflation expectations of economic analysts and the BCRD forecasting system, indicate that inflation would remain around the core value of the target range by 2020.

In the international environment, uncertainty factors are still persisting, associated with socio-political tensions in various regions of the world and trade disputes between major economies, which have influenced a slowdown in the global economy. More recently, volatility in international financial markets has increased as a result of the potential impact that coronavirus can have on the Chinese economy and on global growth. Indeed, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) estimates that the global economy would expand by 2.9% in 2019, the lowest rate in a decade, and would recover slightly to 3.3% by 2020. On the other hand, Consensus Forecasts, which brings together leading analyst firms that make international projections, maintains the forecast of moderate global growth of 2.5% for 2019 and 2020.

Economic activity in the United States of America has gradually slowed from 2.9% growth in 2018 to 2.3% in 2019, while IMF projections indicate a 2.0% expansion in 2020 for the world's main economy. In this context and with low inflationary pressures, the Federal Reserve maintains an accommodative monetary stance, continuing liquidity provision programmes to the financial system through repurchase agreements (REPOS) and Treasury bill purchases on the secondary market, with the aim of reducing short-term interest rates. Importantly, the Fed and market analysts do not anticipate adjustments to the benchmark interest rate this year. As for the Euro Area, economic growth has deteriorated from 1.9% in 2018 to 1.2% at the end of 2019, projecting 1.3% by 2020.

The slowdown in this bloc of countries has been influenced by the weak performance of the industrial sector in its major economies and the slowdown in international trade. Considering the absence of inflationary pressures, the European Central Bank continues to implement a package of expansionary measures, including a negative interest rate for short-term deposits of financial institutions, the liquidity provision programme for the channelling of credit to the private sector, and the purchase of sovereign bonds on the secondary market.

On the other hand, in Latin America, the deterioration of economic activity has been accentuated as a result of socio-political conflicts in several of the countries of the region. Thus, the IMF estimates regional growth of just 0.1% for 2019 and a recovery of 1.6% in 2020. The region's economic slowdown during 2019 has been influenced by negative growth rates in Mexico, Venezuela, Nicaragua, Argentina, Ecuador and Paraguay, as well as the modest expansion of Brazil and the negative impact of social demonstrations in Chile, Bolivia and Colombia.

In terms of raw materials, the price of Texas' intermediate oil averaged $58 during the month of January, conditioned by geopolitical conflicts in crude oil-producing countries and by the prospects for lower global demand. On the other hand, the price of gold has remained at high levels, ranking above $1,550 per troy ounce during the month of January, being used as a haven of value in an environment of high uncertainty. This behaviour of oil and gold prices favors the Dominican Republic's terms of trade and benefits the external sector of the economy.

In the domestic context, the economy continues to react favourably to monetary easing measures, which have boosted domestic demand through increased consumption and private investment from the second half of 2019. Indeed, economic activity showed significant dynamism over the past December as year-on-year growth of 6.7% was recorded. Thus, gross domestic product (GDP) growth reached 5.1% in 2019, consistent with the potential growth of the economy.

The expansionary monetary measures implemented from June 2019, through the reduction of 100 basis points of the monetary policy rate and the release of more than RD$34 billion of legal lace resources to the productive sectors, contributed to the increase of private credit in national currency , while total private loans, which include domestic and foreign currency, increased by more than RD$127 billion in this period. This dynamism of private credit has been maintained at the beginning of this year, with an expansion rate of more than 12% year-on-year at the end of January. Favourable monetary conditions are expected to continue to support the dynamism of domestic demand, projecting economic growth of around 5.0% - 5.3% during 2020.

In the external sector, the Balance of Payments current account had a deficit of 1.4% of GDP, similar to that of 2018 and lower than the average in the last ten years. In terms of foreign exchange-generating activities, foreign direct investment reached US$3,012.8 million during 2019 and remittances received amounted to US$7,087.2 million, offsetting the recent moderation of tourism which, despite being affected by the spread of negative news, generated revenue of US$7,468.1 million. On the other hand, the process of consolidation of public finances has been continued, with a deficit of 2.3% of GDP and a primary surplus of 0.6% of GDP at the end of 2019.

In this complex international environment, the Dominican Republic has managed to strengthen its macroeconomic fundamentals, maintaining relative exchange rate stability and continuing the process of accumulation of International Reserves, which ended 2019 at US$8,781.8 million, its highest historical level for a year-end closing, equivalent to 4.9 months of import coverage and approximately 10% of GDP.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to drive monetary policy towards achieving its inflation target and the smooth functioning of financial and payment systems, thus contributing to the maintenance of macroeconomic stability. In this sense, the institution will continue to monitor the moderation of the world economy and factors of uncertainty both externally and internally and its impact on aggregate demand, being prepared to continue to react in a timely manner to factors that may generate deviations from the inflation target and affect Dominican economic growth.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic, at its Monetary Policy meeting in February 2012, decided to maintain its Monetary Policy Rate unchanged at 6.75% per annum. At the same time, it decided to leave the Lombard Interest Rate unchanged at 9.0% per annum.

The decision regarding the reference rate is based on the fact that inflation continues to converge to the goal of 5.5% <U+00B1> 1% for 2012. The behavior of the main macroeconomic variables and the forecast models do not foresee deviations from the inflation target in the policy horizon for this year. In January 2012, inflation was 0.4%, contributing to the year-on-year rate being reduced for the fifth month, registering 6.9% after reaching a maximum of 10.2% in August 2011. This downward trend is also reflected in inflation the year-on-year core which was 4.8% at the end of the month.

In the external context, the outlook for moderate growth in the world economy remains, so that, in the absence of disruptions, a reduction in global inflationary pressures is expected. Recent indicators of economic activity and employment show that the United States would continue to recover gradually, while Europe and Japan would face recessionary conditions during 2012. Emerging economies maintain a positive outlook, although more moderate than last year.

The recent agreement between the IMF and the European Union for another rescue to Greece is encouraging for the markets, but international financial risks would remain high in the short term while the prices of primary goods would remain above their historical averages. . Tensions in the Middle East continue to be a focus of geopolitical risk for the world economy.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity and domestic demand develop within the foreseen in the most recent Monetary Policy Report. Credit to the private sector is expanding at a rate similar to that recorded at the end of 2011, while inflation expectations remain around the 2012 target.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve the inflation target of 5.5% <U+00B1> 1% for 2012, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the global and domestic economy in order to react in a timely manner to risks related to the price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic, in its Monetary Policy Meeting of February 2013, decided to keep its Monetary Policy Interest Rate (MPR) unchanged at 5.00% per annum.

The decision on the reference interest rate takes into account that the forecast models indicate that in the monetary policy horizon, inflation would be within the goal of 5.0% <U+00B1> 1 percentage point in 2013 and 4.5% <U+00B1> 1 point. percentage in 2014. Likewise, market expectations are close to the inflation target. In January, year-on-year inflation reached 4.76%, as a result of the impact of the fiscal reform that caused a monthly inflation of 1.26%.

In the external context, economic activity in the United States of America (USA) continued to grow at a moderate pace, expanding 2.2% in 2012, while in the Euro Zone (ZE) the recession persisted at the end of the year with a fall in GDP. of 0.5%. However, for 2013, the Consensus Forecast projects a slightly lower growth of 1.9% in the US, as well as a moderation of the recession in the ZE, foreseeing a fall of 0.2% for the current year.

Although fiscal risks have moderated in the US, political pressures persist related to cuts in public spending that could affect economic performance. In the European Union there is still no definitive solution to the fiscal and debt crisis and, with the exception of Germany, the main economies are experiencing recessive or zero growth conditions. On the other hand, international financial markets have better liquidity conditions, which could facilitate the flow of capital to emerging economies. Although the prices of most primary goods experienced a decrease in 2012, they still remain above their historical levels.

In the domestic sphere, economic growth in 2012 was 3.9%, higher than the Latin American average of 3.1%, according to ECLAC. This growth was in line with the forecast in the macroeconomic framework. Credit to the private sector in national currency continues showing a recovery and projections seem to indicate that by the end of the year the financing would be growing above the nominal product. Greater credit would allow a faster recovery of consumption and private investment, helping production expand to levels closer to its potential capacity.

El Banco Central reafirma su compromiso de conducir la pol<ed>tica monetaria al logro de su meta de inflaci<f3>n, a la vez que seguir<e1> monitoreando la evoluci<f3>n de la econom<ed>a mundial y la coyuntura dom<e9>stica, a fin de reaccionar oportunamente ante riesgos sobre la estabilidad de precios y el buen funcionamiento de los sistemas financiero y de pagos.
En su reuni<f3>n de pol<ed>tica monetaria de febrero de 2014, el Banco Central de la Rep<fa>blica Dominicana decidi<f3> mantener la tasa de pol<ed>tica monetaria (TPM) en 6.25 % anual.

La decisi<f3>n respecto a la tasa de referencia tom<f3> en consideraci<f3>n el balance de riesgos en torno a las proyecciones de inflaci<f3>n y las expectativas del mercado. La tasa interanual de inflaci<f3>n disminuy<f3> por sexto mes consecutivo, cerrando en enero de 2014 en 2.82%. Esta tasa de inflaci<f3>n se encuentra por debajo del extremo inferior del rango-meta de 4.5% <U+00B1> 1%. En t<e9>rminos mensuales, la inflaci<f3>n fue de 0.23% en el primer mes del a<f1>o, muy por debajo de lo previsto. Del mismo modo, la inflaci<f3>n subyacente interanual,  la cual se asocia a las presiones de inflaci<f3>n de origen monetario, se redujo a 3.43%.

En el contexto externo, el entorno internacional relevante se caracteriza por un escenario de recuperaci<f3>n en las econom<ed>as desarrolladas, especialmente en Estados Unidos de Am<e9>rica (EUA), mientras algunas de las econom<ed>as emergentes m<e1>s grandes, con fundamentos macroecon<f3>micos d<e9>biles, enfrentan salidas de capitales. Seg<fa>n las <fa>ltimas proyecciones del Consensus Forecast, EUA crecer<ed>a 2.9% en 2014 y 3.0% en 2015, mientras la inflaci<f3>n se mantendr<ed>a por debajo de 2.0% durante ese periodo. Ante el d<e9>bil crecimiento de los precios, se espera que la Reserva Federal mantenga las tasas de inter<e9>s en los niveles actuales, entre 0 y 0.25%, al menos hasta 2015.

In the Euro Zone, economic activity decreased by 0.4% in 2013, but the Consensus Forecast projects an important recovery in 2014 and 2015, with positive growth of 1.0% and 1.4%, respectively. Given that the world economy is still growing below its potential level, it is expected that both in this year and in 2015, inflationary pressures on the world economy will remain low. Although some prices of raw materials have increased in international markets, there is a consensus that this behavior is transitory and an important moderation is expected in the coming months.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity and domestic demand are evolving positively, projecting a growth rate, according to the Macroeconomic Framework, around 4.5% in 2014, which would allow production to approach its potential level to the end of the year. Credit to the private sector in national currency continues to expand at a rate above the nominal product, around 13.0% in year-on-year terms, while the outlook for activities related to foreign trade improves, projecting a current account deficit of 4.0% of the Gross Domestic Product in 2014.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation in order to take the necessary measures against risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting for the month of February 2015, the Central Bank decided to maintain its monetary policy interest rate (MPR) at 6.25% per annum.

The decision on the reference interest rate was taken based on the analysis of the perspectives and the balance of risks around the inflation projections. In that sense, although the year-on-year inflation for January was only 1.16%, below the target of this year of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1%, the projections continue indicating that in the monetary policy horizon, inflation would converge to your medium-term goal. Additionally, the Central Bank took into account in its decision the main national macroeconomic indicators and market expectations, as well as the relevant international environment. It is important to note that core inflation, related to the monetary conditions of the economy, was 2.91%, a rate that corresponds to the Monetary Program.

In the external sphere, the monetary policy implemented by the main developed economies would remain expansive, at least until the last quarter of the year. The United States of America (USA) is expected to continue consolidating its recovery, projected a growth of 3.2% in 2015, according to Consensus Forecast. If this situation were maintained, the country's commercial exchange with the United States would benefit. Likewise, the Euro Zone and Japan maintain monetary stimuli with the aim of boosting economic growth in the short term. While the Euro Zone would register an expansion rate of 1.2%, Japan would grow around 1.3%. On the other hand, Latin America shows a moderate growth scenario with forecasts of around 1.3% for 2015, a slightly higher increase than that reached in the previous year.

In international capital markets, financial conditions have not presented major changes in the last month and a gradual improvement in liquidity is expected, which would facilitate the flow of capital to emerging economies. On the other hand, the US dollar has strengthened in the last year to the extent that the market recognizes the best performance of the US economy compared to other developed economies. The prices of basic goods continue below their levels of the last five years, and in the case of oil, according to the International Energy Agency (EIA), the price would be on average at US $ 55 a barrel in 2015. This forecast It would favor the behavior of the fiscal accounts and the current account of the balance of payments. Based on this average oil price, the country could generate a saving of around US $ 1,550 million in the oil bill.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity maintained its dynamism, growing 7.3% in 2014. In February, the annual growth rate of credit to the private sector in national currency was 14.5%, while total credit to the private sector, including financing in foreign currency, it would expand by around 18.0%, with respect to the same month of the previous year. In the area of ??fiscal policy, budget execution remains oriented toward meeting the Central Government's deficit target, around 2.4% of GDP in 2015. Additionally, external accounts point towards a current account deficit around to 2.0% of GDP for the end of the year, facilitating the maintenance of relative stability in the foreign exchange market and a greater accumulation of international reserves.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to implement monetary policy aimed at achieving its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to take the necessary measures against risks to the stability of the economy. prices and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic, in its Monetary Policy Meeting of February 2016, decided to keep its Monetary Policy Interest Rate (MPR) unchanged at 5.00% per annum.

The decision on the reference interest rate takes into account that the forecast models indicate that inflation would converge to the center of the target of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0%, in the monetary policy horizon. Likewise, market expectations are located around the inflation target. It was observed that in the month of January, the interannual inflation rate stood at 2.53%, while the core interannual inflation, which reflects the monetary conditions, decreased to 1.78%. The balance of risks around the inflation projections is balanced, while the relevant international environment for the Dominican economy tends to be favorable, with low oil prices and growth of the main trading partner, the United States of America (USA).

In the external context, the World Economy would grow 2.6% in 2016 and 2.9% in 2017, driven mainly by the behavior of the industrialized economies. According to the Consensus Forecast, the US would grow 2.2% in 2016 and 2.4% in 2017, while the Euro Zone would expand its economic activity by 1.6% and 1.7%, respectively, during those years. Latin America, as a whole, would present a fall in real economic activity of -0.1% in 2016, due to the recession experienced by some of the largest economies in the region such as Venezuela (-6.3%), Brazil (-3.1% ), Argentina (-0.1%) and Ecuador (-0.1%). Likewise, the growth of other important countries in the region would be positive, but it would remain below 3.0%, such as Mexico (2.7%), Chile (2.0%), Colombia (2.5%) and Uruguay (1.9%). ). For 2017 a moderate recovery is expected in the Latin American Region when reaching its Gross Domestic Product, a real expansion of around 2.1%.

Conditions in international stock markets continue to show a high degree of volatility, while capital flows leave emerging economies to more secure destinations. Risk premia for many net exporters of primary goods have increased, mainly due to lower prices of petroleum, industrial metals and some foods. The fall in commodity prices has generated significant depreciations in the currencies of this group of countries, causing deviations in the inflation targets and, consequently, leading several central banks to increase interest rates, contrary to the position of politics that predominates in some advanced economies. One point to note is that in the international exchange markets the appreciation of the dollar against the euro is maintained, albeit more moderately, while long-term interest rates have tended to decrease in advanced countries.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity evolves positively in the short term, growing at a real rate above potential production. Private loans in national currency show year-on-year growth close to 12% at the end of February, exceeding nominal product growth. The macroeconomic fundamentals of the Dominican economy remain strong, reflected in a low current account deficit of around 2.0% of GDP and a moderate estimate of the budget deficit of around 2.3% of GDP for 2016. This behavior of fiscal policy favors the sustainability of public accounts. In a context of solid macroeconomic fundamentals like the current one, it facilitates the maintenance of the relative stability of the exchange rate, as well as the accumulation of international reserves in an amount much higher than the historical average.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation in order to react timely to risks on price stability and good functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting for the month of February 2017, the BCRD decided to maintain the monetary policy rate (MPR) at 5.50% per annum.

The decision on the benchmark interest rate was adopted after a weighted analysis of the balance of risks around the inflation projections, as well as the state of the economy based on its main indicators, market expectations and the international environment relevant. In the month of January, the monthly inflation was 0.62%, while the interannual inflation rate rose to 2.33%. Likewise, core inflation, related to the monetary conditions of the economy, was 1.89%. According to projections, inflation would converge to the goal of 4% <U+00B1> 1% in the first half of this year.

In the international context, according to Consensus Forecast, the world economy would grow 2.8% in 2017, with an expected expansion of around 2.9% by 2018, in line with better growth projections for the United States of America (USA) and with a better expected performance in some emerging economies. In the case of the US, this year's growth would close around 2.3%, improving to 2.4% by 2018. On the other hand, real production in the Euro Zone (ZE) would grow 1.6% in 2017 and 1.5% in 2018. Inflation in these industrialized economies would remain positive, gradually approaching the long-term trend levels. In that sense, inflation rates of 2.5% are expected for the US and 1.6% for the ZE in 2017. By 2018, inflation would be around 2.3% in the US and 1.4% in the ZE. In the case of Latin America, after a fall of GDP of -0.5% in 2016, the region would begin the recovery of economic growth in 2017 by projecting an expansion of 1.6%, improving to 2.5% in 2018.

International prices of primary goods tend towards levels higher than last year's average, especially oil, industrial metals and some foods. It is expected that the normalization process of the US Federal Reserve will continue, increasing the interest rate differential with other industrialized economies, which would continue to drive a path of strengthening the dollar in international markets.

In the domestic sphere, the economy reached an expansion of 6.6% in real terms in 2016, projected growth of around 5.5% for 2017, above its potential and the Latin American average. Credit to the private sector in national currency continues to grow around 12% year-on-year in February, gradually converging to the projected expansion for the nominal product in the current year. The current account of the balance of payments closed with a deficit of 1.5% of GDP in 2016 and the fiscal deficit of the Central Government presented a preliminary record around the stipulated in the modified budget for 2016. These indicators indicate that they have been followed strengthening the foundations of the Dominican economy.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to continue conducting monetary policy aimed at achieving its inflation target and maintaining macroeconomic stability, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to adopt the necessary measures against possible risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting in February 2018, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.25% per annum.

The monetary policy decision was based on an exhaustive analysis of the balance of risks around inflation forecasts, the evolution of the main national macroeconomic indicators, the relevant international environment, market expectations and medium-term projections. Inflation in January 2018 was 0.29%, so that year-on-year inflation stood at 3.86%, slightly below the central value of the target range of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0% established in the Monetary Program. Likewise, core inflation, related to monetary conditions, amounted to 2.43% year-on-year. It is expected that the interannual rate of inflation would remain within the target range in the monetary policy horizon of 24 months.

In the international arena, the outlook for the global economy continues to improve, according to the most recent forecasts of the Consensus Forecast (CFC), while inflation remains contained and labor markets are strengthened. In that sense, CFC estimates an expansion rate of 3.3% for the world economy in 2018, driven by growth of 2.8% in the United States of America (USA) and 2.3% in the Euro Zone (ZE). By 2019, the economic dynamism of the industrialized nations is expected to moderate slightly, with the US reaching a growth of 2.4% and the ZE of 1.9%. Likewise, in the developed world, inflationary pressures would remain moderate, with US inflation estimated at 2.3% in 2018 and 2.2% in 2019, and for the ZE a price increase of 1.5% in both years.

In the case of Latin America (AL), the recovery process would continue throughout the region with the exception of Venezuela, with an estimated growth of 2.6% for 2018 and 2.9% for 2019. International financial conditions remain favorable for emerging economies in the region. an environment of abundant liquidity worldwide. However, in the medium term, these conditions could change as the US fiscal reform and the monetary normalization of the Federal Reserve (FED) incentivize the return of capital to the United States. Precisely, in the press release published at the end of his last visit to the country, the IMF identified as a risk factor for the Dominican economy the possibility of facing more restrictive international financial conditions than expected. In addition, he pointed out as other important risk factors, the increase in international oil prices and weaker external demand than expected.

In the domestic context, the economy continues to react favorably to the monetary easing measures implemented in the last two quarters of last year. In that sense, preliminary information of the Monthly Indicator of Economic Activity (IMAE) show a year-on-year growth of 7.0% in the month of January. Likewise, credit to the private sector in national currency grew around 12.0% year-on-year, while at the same time improving the outlook for private investors, as is perceived in the evolution of the indicators of industrial confidence and business climate, corresponding to the Business Opinion Survey implemented by the BCRD. Projection models indicate that in the current year, economic growth could be between 5.5% and 6.0%.

On the fiscal policy side, capital spending experienced a notable recovery in the second half of 2017, which contributed to the recovery of economic activity. In the external sector, the current account closed last year with a deficit of -0.2% of GDP, which allowed historical international reserves to be accumulated, achieving a coverage of 4.4 months of imports. So far this year, international reserves have continued to rise, exceeding the record figure of US $ 8,000 million. The favorable evolution of the international environment would induce more dynamism in the foreign currency generating activities, which would continue to facilitate the relative stability of the exchange market.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy aimed at achieving the inflation target and maintaining macroeconomic stability. In that sense, it will continue to monitor the evolution of the world and national economy, in order to adopt the necessary measures against possible risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting in February 2019, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.50% per annum.

The decision to leave the reference rate unchanged is based on a detailed analysis of the risk balance around inflation forecasts, including information from international and domestic macroeconomic indicators, market expectations and medium-term projections. Inflation for the month of January 2019 was negative, registering a variation of -0.17% mainly influenced by the price behavior of the transportation and housing groups. In that sense, year-on-year inflation continued to decelerate to 0.71%, while core inflation, which excludes the prices of the most volatile goods and services, stood at 2.38%. The forecast system indicates that headline inflation would converge gradually to the center of the target range of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0% in the year 2020.

In the external environment, forecasts are maintained that the world economy would grow 2.9% during 2019 and 2.8% in 2020, according to the Consensus Forecast (CFC). In the short term, the growth of global economic activity would continue to be driven by the United States of America (USA), however, there are some signs of moderation in its medium-term growth. Indeed, Consensus Forecast estimates that the US would expand 2.5% in 2019 and 1.8% in 2020. In this context and before a reduction in inflationary pressures, the Federal Reserve has paused in the increases of its benchmark interest rate, that is, in the normalization process of its monetary policy, which is associated with greater uncertainty in the domestic and international environment facing the US.

On the other hand, Consensus Forecast continues to downgrade the growth prospects of the Euro Zone (ZE), estimating an expansion of 1.3% in 2019 and 1.4% in 2020. This moderation is influenced by the slowdown in some of its main economies , like Germany, Italy and France. Meanwhile, inflation projections for this group of countries are below their target, so it is expected that the European Central Bank will maintain its monetary policy stance in the medium term.

In the case of Latin America, the region is projected to grow 1.9% in 2019 and 2.5% in 2020, led by the Dominican Republic, Panama, Bolivia and Paraguay. In that order, the largest economy in the region, Brazil, having emerged from a recession, projects an economic growth of 2.4% in 2019, after the implementation of a stabilization and adjustment program that included, among other economic policies, increases salaries of 1.8% in 2018 and 4.6% in 2019. Economies with weak macroeconomic fundamentals, such as Venezuela, Argentina and Nicaragua, would remain in recession this year.

In terms of raw materials, the price of oil continues to increase gradually, reaching an average of about US $ 55 per barrel in February. The price of crude oil has been influenced by new cuts by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC), especially in Saudi Arabia, as well as a lower supply from Venezuela.

Domestically, in the current year economic activity maintains growth above potential, driven mainly by investment and private consumption, in a context of low inflationary pressures. At the end of February 2019, an expansion of credit to the private sector in national currency was observed around 10.5% year-on-year, consistent with the dynamism of the economy and monetary conditions that remain favorable.

On the fiscal policy side, during 2018 the moderation of disbursements was maintained, measured by total spending, as growth of 5.9% was observed, while the expansion of revenues reached 12.5% ??year-on-year. By 2019, the deficit of the Central Government is expected to close at 1.7% of GDP, as contemplated by the National Budget. The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic is attentive to the evolution of the normalization of the monetary policy of the United States, as well as to the behavior of international financial conditions and the global oil price, being prepared to react in a timely manner before any factor that may generate inflationary deviations. In this sense, the issuing entity reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems, thus contributing to the maintenance of macroeconomic stability.
BCRD maintains its monetary policy rate at 4.50% per year
At its monetary policy meeting in February 2020, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 4.50% per annum.

The benchmark decision is based on detailed risk balance analysis for inflation forecasts, including international and domestic macroeconomic indicators, market expectations and medium-term projections. January's monthly inflation was 0.33%, while underlying inflation, reflecting monetary conditions, stood at 2.41% in January. On the other hand, year-on-year inflation, i.e. from January 2019 to January 2020, stood at 4.17%, remaining within the target range of 4.0% to 1.0%. Going forward, both the inflation expectations of economic analysts and the BCRD forecasting system, indicate that inflation would remain around the core value of the target range by 2020.

In the international environment, uncertainty about the negative impact coronavirus is having on the Chinese economy and its potential effect on global growth has increased, exacerbating the process of slowing down the global economy that had been affected by trade disputes and geopolitical tensions in different regions of the world. Importantly, prior to the more accelerated spread of coronavirus in recent weeks, Consensus Forecasts (CFC), which brings together leading analyst firms making international projections, had projected a moderation of global growth, from 2.5% in 2019 to 2.4% by 2020. If the spread trend of the virus continues, these projections are expected to continue to be corrected downwards due to their effects on global production, trade and tourism.

In the United States of America, economic activity has gradually slowed as a result of slowing private investment and exports. Indeed, Consensus Forecasts projects that U.S. growth would moderate from 2.3% in 2019 to 1.9% by 2020. In this context and with low inflationary pressures, the Federal Reserve maintains an accommodative monetary stance, continuing liquidity provision programs to the financial system through repurchase agreements (REPOS) of up to USD 125 billion and purchases of Treasury bills on the secondary market for USD 60 billion per month. In the face of the spread of the coronavirus that has caused a widespread decline in the world's major stock markets, Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said last Friday that there are still warnings of increased risks to the U.S. economy and ready to use its tools, which would imply further reductions in the federal fund interest rate this year.

As for the Eurozone, economic growth has deteriorated to 1.2% at the end of 2019 and Consensus plans an even smaller expansion of 0.9% by 2020. The slowdown in this bloc of countries has been influenced by the weak performance of the industrial sector in its major economies and the slowdown in international trade. Considering the absence of inflationary pressures, the European Central Bank continues to implement a package of expansionary measures including a negative interest rate for short-term deposits of financial institutions, the liquidity provision programme for the channelling of credit to the private sector and the purchase of sovereign debt securities on the secondary market for 20 billion euros per month.

On the other hand, Latin America has accentuated the weakening of economic activity as a result of socio-political conflicts in several of the countries of the region. Thus, the IMF estimates that the region would have grown by just 0.1% in 2019 and projects a 1.6% recovery by 2020. The region's economic slowdown during 2019 has been influenced by negative growth rates in Mexico, Venezuela, Nicaragua, Argentina and Ecuador, as well as the modest expansion of Brazil and the negative impact of social demonstrations in Chile, Bolivia and Colombia.

It should be noted that, given the potential impact of coronavirus, the economic prospects of the largest economies in the Latin American region could deteriorate beyond expectations, owing to their trade ties with China and its status as exporters of primary goods, mainly food and metals.

Indeed, the price of most commodities has declined significantly, noting that the price of Texas' intermediate oil closed february below $45 a barrel, conditioned by the prospects for lower global demand. However, the price of gold has remained high, ranking above $1,500 per troy ounce at the close of February, as it was used as a haven of value in an environment of high uncertainty. This behaviour of oil and gold prices favors the Dominican Republic's terms of trade and benefits the external sector of the economy.

In the domestic context, the economy has reacted favourably to monetary easing measures, which boosted domestic demand through increased consumption and private investment, resulting in year-on-year growth of 5.1% in 2019, the highest in Latin America. At the end of February, private credit in national currency has continued to show high dynamism, reflected in an expansion rate of more than 12% year-on-year. Favourable monetary conditions are expected to continue to support domestic demand and the economy is expected to expand around its potential by 2020.

Because in recent years the Dominican Republic has strengthened its macroeconomic fundamentals, as a country it is better prepared than other emerging economies to navigate the adverse international landscape, characterized by high uncertainty due to the potential impact of coronavirus on the world economy. In this context, it is necessary to preserve economic stability, giving security and certainty to private actors in such a way as to maintain an enabling environment to sustain investment and growth, especially in a domestic environment affected by the election cycle.

In the external sector, foreign exchange-generating activities such as foreign direct investment and remittances continue to perform well, compensating for recent tourism moderation and contributing to maintaining relative exchange rate stability and continuing to strengthen The International Reserves, which currently amount to almost 10% of GDP. On the other hand, in the fiscal sector, the process of consolidation of public finances is maintained, with a deficit of 2.2% of GDP projected to be achieved at the end of this year.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to drive monetary policy towards achieving its inflation target and the smooth functioning of financial and payment systems, thus contributing to the maintenance of macroeconomic stability. In this sense, the institution will continue to monitor the potential impact of the coronavirus on the world economy and the other factors of uncertainty both externally and internally and its effects on aggregate demand, being prepared to continue to react in a timely manner to factors that may generate deviations from the inflation target and affect Dominican economic growth.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic, at its March 2012 Monetary Policy meeting, decided to maintain its Monetary Policy Rate unchanged at 6.75% per annum. At the same time, it decided to leave the Lombard Interest Rate unchanged at 9.0% per annum.

The decision regarding the reference rate is based on the fact that, in the month of February, the year-on-year rate of inflation fell to 6.0%, reaching within the target of 5.5% <U+00B1> 1% for 2012. Likewise, the interannual core inflation it was reduced to 4.25% at the end of February, below its historical average. Given that the factors that affect the inflation forecasts have not changed significantly since the previous monetary policy meeting, the projections suggest that inflation would remain within the goal established in the Monetary Program.

In the external context, the United States indicators confirm the perspective of gradual recovery of that economy, while a moderation in the Asian economies is expected, mainly China and India. In Europe, recessive conditions remain, although there is a perception that fiscal adjustments in some countries and the restructuring of Greek debt have contributed to moderate international financial risks. The greater uncertainty facing this international scenario is related to the recent volatility of oil prices.

Latin America presents a favorable panorama, although not free of risks, according to the International Monetary Fund. Additionally, in its last macroeconomic report for the region, the Inter-American Development Bank considered that the region would face positive economic conditions in 2012, assuming a scenario with improvements in the US economy, a slight moderation in the Chinese economy and a short-term crisis. in Europe.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity and domestic demand are evolving within the provisions of the last Monetary Policy Report. Credit to the private sector is expanding at a rate close to 11%, consistent with the expansion of nominal GDP, while market inflation expectations remain around the target of 2012. So far this year, the pressures inflation have remained low, reaching inflation 0.35% in the month of February and an accumulated 0.79% during the first two months of the year. This has contributed to the fact that inter-annual inflation maintained its downward trend and that its level has converged to the target during the first quarter of this year, consistent with that indicated in previous press releases.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve the inflation target of 5.5% <U+00B1> 1% for 2012, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the global and domestic economy in order to react in a timely manner to risks related to the price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic, in its Monetary Policy Meeting of March 2013, decided to keep its Monetary Policy Interest Rate (MPR) at 5.00% per annum. The decision on the reference interest rate takes into account that the forecast models predict that inflation would be within the target in the monetary policy horizon. In the same way, market expectations are close to this objective. In the month of February, the inflation rate was 0.33%. In interannual terms, general inflation stood at 4.73%, while core inflation rose to 5.15%, both within the target range for the current year.

In the external context, the US economy maintains moderate growth with important signs of recovery in key markets such as real estate. The Euro Zone continues to present a recessive panorama with a delicate financial and fiscal situation. According to the Economic Consensus (Consensus Forecast), the United States of America would be growing slightly below 2.0% in the current year, while the Euro Zone would register a fall in its economic activity of around 0.3%, which would imply two consecutive years of negative growth In Latin America, although forecasts point to higher growth than in 2012, the region could be affected by a fall in commodity prices that would imply more unfavorable terms of trade for emerging economies.

In the domestic sphere, production and domestic demand evolve moderately, below the potential production capacity of the economy. Credit to the private sector in national currency registered its highest growth in March 2013 in the last nine months. In year-on-year terms, private loans in local currency of all financial institutions grew above 5.0% and it is projected that by the end of the year their expansion would be in line with the nominal product. The recovery of private credit would contribute to a more rapid recovery of consumption and private investment, which would help to continue closing the output gap.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation in order to adopt new measures in the face of risks on price stability and the good functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its March 2014 monetary policy meeting, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic decided to maintain the monetary policy interest rate at 6.25% per annum.

The decision regarding the reference rate takes into account the revision of the risk balance around the inflation projections and the market expectations. After decreasing in the previous six months, the year-on-year rate of inflation remained practically unchanged in February, at 2.84%, below the lower end of the target range of 4.5% <U+00B1> 1%. This result was due to a monthly variation of 0.58% in the second month of the year. Likewise, the interannual core inflation was reduced to 3.25%.

In the external context, a scenario of recovery is maintained in the developed economies, especially in the United States, where the indicators of conjuncture show a better performance in private consumption, the housing market and the external sector, which allows us to foresee growth of 2.8% for the current year in an environment of low interest rates and lower unemployment. In the Euro Zone, a moderate recovery is estimated for 2014, around 1.1%, according to the Consensus Forecast. Emerging economies continue to grow, albeit at a more moderate pace. In the case of Latin America, the consensus points to a growth of 2.5% for 2014, in an environment of falling terms of trade in the region and lower liquidity in international markets. In recent months, the prices of some raw materials, particularly oil, as well as international financial conditions have remained relatively stable. The reduction in inflationary pressures worldwide would help to keep interest rates low for the rest of the year.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity and domestic demand maintain a healthy performance, showing a growth trend of around 5.0% in February, according to preliminary figures of the Monthly Index of Economic Activity. In the financial sector, credit to the private sector in national currency continues to expand at an interannual rate close to 13.0% in March and it is expected that by the end of the year, its growth will be around the expansion of the nominal product between 8.0 and 10.0%. The current account deficit projects to close the year at 4.2% of GDP, due to an improvement in net exports, tourism and free zones. Additionally, a positive performance of Foreign Direct Investment is expected which, together with remittances, would increase the flow of foreign currency to the Dominican economy and contribute to maintain the relative stability of the exchange rate.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation in order to take the necessary measures against risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.

At its monetary policy meeting in March 2015, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to reduce its monetary policy interest rate (MPR) by 50 basis points, from 6.25% per annum to 5.75% per annum, to as of April 1, 2015. According to the BCRD's short-term liquidity management scheme, the rate of paid deposits (overnight) was reduced to 4.25% per annum. Likewise, the rate of expansion facilities, through purchases of securities with repurchase agreements (repos), decreased to 7.25% per annum.

The decision on the reference rate was adopted taking into consideration the analysis of the perspectives of the main macroeconomic variables, especially the balance of risks around the inflation projections, as well as the expectations of the market and the relevant international environment.
