Externally, the recovery of the developed economies continues, mainly the United States of America, where an economic growth rate close to 2.7% is expected in 2014, in an environment of low inflation and without changes in the policy interest rate. in the next months. In the Eurozone, the outlook for moderate recovery remains around 1.2% for 2014, according to the Consensus Forecast. Emerging economies continue to project a lower rate of expansion than in previous years. In the case of Latin America, the consensus points to 2.3% growth for 2014, in an environment of reduced terms of trade in the region and lower liquidity in international markets. In recent months, the prices of some raw materials, particularly oil and food, have remained stable. The absence of inflationary pressures worldwide would favor low interest rates in developed countries for the rest of the year.

In the domestic sphere, the trend-cycle of the Monthly Indicator of Economic Activity (IMAE) grows around 5.1% at the end of the first quarter and it is expected that the real Gross Domestic Product will increase around 4.5% in 2014, according to what is planned in the macroeconomic framework. At the same time, credit to the private sector in national currency expanded above 14.5% at the end of March and it is expected that it would be growing at a rate close to 10.0% at the end of the year, a rhythm consistent with the expected path in GDP nominal. Additionally, the influx of foreign currency into the economy would be improving due to the entry of important resources from the recent placement of the sovereign bond, to a more favorable behavior of exports of goods and services and remittances, given the improvement in the economy of our main business partner. This inflow of resources would help maintain the relative stability of the exchange rate.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation in order to take the necessary measures against risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.

En su reuni<f3>n de pol<ed>tica monetaria del mes de abril de 2015, el Banco Central decidi<f3> reducir su tasa de inter<e9>s de pol<ed>tica monetaria en 50 puntos b<e1>sicos, de 5.75% anual a 5.25% anual, a partir del 1ro de mayo de 2015. De acuerdo al esquema de gesti<f3>n de liquidez de corto plazo del BCRD, la tasa de dep<f3>sitos remunerados (overnight) se redujo a 3.75% anual. Igualmente, la tasa de facilidades de expansi<f3>n (repos), disminuy<f3> a 6.75% anual.

La decisi<f3>n sobre la tasa de referencia fue adoptada a partir del an<e1>lisis de las perspectivas de las principales variables macroecon<f3>micas, especialmente el balance de riesgos en torno a las proyecciones de inflaci<f3>n, las expectativas del mercado sobre la trayectoria futura de esta variable, el crecimiento econ<f3>mico y el mercado cambiario, as<ed> como la evaluaci<f3>n del entorno internacional relevante para la econom<ed>a dominicana.

La tasa interanual de inflaci<f3>n se mantuvo por debajo de la meta de 4.0% <U+00B1> 1%, al descender a  0.64% en el mes de marzo. Por otro lado, la inflaci<f3>n acumulada durante los tres primeros meses del a<f1>o fue de 0.16%. Las proyecciones indican que la inflaci<f3>n se mantendr<ed>a por debajo del l<ed>mite inferior de la meta establecida en el Programa Monetario para 2015. Adem<e1>s, en el mes de marzo la inflaci<f3>n subyacente, relacionada con las condiciones monetarias de la econom<ed>a, fue de 2.59% interanual.

En el <e1>mbito externo, los datos disponibles confirman que el proceso de recuperaci<f3>n de las econom<ed>as desarrolladas se mantiene en curso, apoyado por pol<ed>ticas monetarias expansivas. No obstante, para los Estados Unidos de Am<e9>rica (EUA), cifras preliminares muestran que la econom<ed>a registr<f3> un crecimiento inter-trimestral anualizado en enero- marzo de 0.2%, tasa por debajo de lo esperado por el mercado. Bajo esta perspectiva, Consensus Forecast ajust<f3> sus pron<f3>sticos de crecimiento de EUA para 2015, de 3.1% a 2.9%, a su vez el Fondo Monetario Internacional corrigi<f3> a la baja su proyecci<f3>n de 3.6% a 3.1% para el presente a<f1>o.

Por otro lado, las perspectivas para la Eurozona han mejorado ajust<e1>ndose al alza sus proyecciones de crecimiento para 2015, de 1.1% en el reporte de marzo a 1.5% en abril, en tanto que Jap<f3>n crecer<ed>a en 1.0% en el presente a<f1>o. China ha mostrado se<f1>ales de ralentizaci<f3>n y su crecimiento estar<ed>a por debajo de 7.0% en 2015. En Am<e9>rica Latina, las previsiones de expansi<f3>n econ<f3>mica de Consensus Forecast han sido reducidas de 0.8% a 0.5% para 2015. Las condiciones financieras internacionales mejoraron en el <fa>ltimo mes, mientras el d<f3>lar contin<fa>a exhibiendo fortaleza, al tiempo que los precios del petr<f3>leo se sit<fa>an entre US$50 y US$60 por barril. Otros commodities exhiben un comportamiento similar, registrando importantes reducciones en sus precios.

En el <e1>mbito dom<e9>stico, la actividad econ<f3>mica evoluciona de manera favorable, creciendo el indicador mensual de actividad econ<f3>mica (IMAE) 6.5% en t<e9>rminos interanuales durante los dos primeros meses del a<f1>o. Asimismo, la tasa de crecimiento anual del cr<e9>dito al sector privado en moneda nacional fue de alrededor de 12.5% en abril, respecto a igual mes de a<f1>o anterior. En cuanto a la pol<ed>tica fiscal, la ejecuci<f3>n presupuestaria apunta a que se cumplir<ed>a la meta de d<e9>ficit del Gobierno Central, en torno a 2.4% del PIB en 2015. Las recaudaciones fiscales crecen alrededor de 10.5%, por encima de lo estimado en el  Presupuesto 2015. Adicionalmente, las cuentas externas apuntan hacia un d<e9>ficit de cuenta corriente en torno al 2.0% del PIB para el cierre del a<f1>o, facilitando la estabilidad relativa en el mercado cambiario y la acumulaci<f3>n de reservas internacionales por encima de lo planeado en el Programa Monetario.

El Banco Central ratifica su compromiso de implementar la pol<ed>tica monetaria orientada al logro de su meta de inflaci<f3>n, a la vez que seguir<e1> monitoreando la evoluci<f3>n de la econom<ed>a mundial y la coyuntura dom<e9>stica, a fin de adoptar las medidas necesarias ante riesgos sobre la estabilidad de precios y el buen funcionamiento de los sistemas financiero y de pagos.
The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic, in its Monetary Policy Meeting of April 2016, decided to keep the Monetary Policy Rate (MPR) at 5.00% per annum.

The decision on the reference interest rate takes into account that the forecast models predict that inflation would converge to the lower range of the target of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0% in the monetary policy horizon. In the same way, market expectations are placed around this prediction. In March, the interannual inflation rate stood at 1.59%, while the interannual core inflation, related to monetary conditions, reached 1.52%. It should be noted that in the first quarter of the year, the Dominican economy accumulated a general inflation of -0.58%.

In the external context, the behavior of the world economy is influenced by a mixed picture in which advanced economies, on average, show a moderate recovery, while emerging markets remain relatively stagnant. In this environment, according to Consensus Forecast, the world economy would grow 2.4% in 2016 and 2.8% in 2017. The United States of America (USA) would expand around 2.0% in 2016 and 2.4% in 2017, while the Euro Zone would grow in 1.5% and 1.6%, during those years, respectively.

Latin America (AL), as a whole, would present a contraction in its production of -0.6% in 2016, due to the recession experienced by Venezuela (-7.8%), Brazil (-3.8%), Argentina (-1.1%) and Ecuador (-1.0%), without taking into account the economic impact of the recent earthquake. Likewise, the growth of other important countries in the region would be positive, but it would remain below the average of the last 5 years. Such is the case of Mexico (2.4%), Chile (1.8%), Colombia (2.4%) and Uruguay (1.5%). For 2017, a moderate recovery of LA is expected with a growth rate of around 2.0%.

Recently, the prices of some primary goods, particularly oil, have shown an upward trend, surpassing, in the case of this commodity, US $ 45 per barrel. International financial markets have been relatively calm, moderating restrictive financial conditions, while long-term interest rates in advanced countries are historically low.

Internally, economic activity evolves positively in the short term. According to preliminary information, the Gross Domestic Product grew by 6.1% in the first quarter of 2016. In that sense, credit to the private sector in national currency registered an annual growth rate of around 13% in April, higher than the expected expansion of nominal GDP. It should be noted that the open unemployment rate fell from 6.0% to 5.7%, from April 2015 to April 2016 and the rate of expanded unemployment was 13.3%, the lowest of the last two decades.

Additionally, for 2016 it is estimated that the current account deficit will be around 1.9% of GDP, while the budget deficit closes around 2.3% of GDP. In a context of solid macroeconomic fundamentals like the current one, it facilitates the maintenance of the relative stability of the exchange rate, as well as an accumulation of international reserves over and above what is planned in the Monetary Program and the sustainability of public finances.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation in order to adopt new measures in the face of risks on price stability and the good functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting in April 2017, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.75% per annum.

The decision regarding the reference rate resulted from a comprehensive analysis of the balance of risks around inflation projections including the main national macroeconomic indicators, market expectations and the relevant international environment for the Dominican economy. As of March 2017, accumulated inflation in the first quarter stood at 0.84%. In interannual terms, inflation stood at 3.14%, remaining within the range established in the Monetary Program of 4% <U+00B1> 1%. The forecast system indicates that inflation would continue within the target range in the current year.

Externally, the world economy would grow 3.5% in 2017 and 3.6% in 2018, according to the IMF. For Consensus Forecast, the developed economies would continue showing a high dynamism. In that sense, the United States of America (USA) presents a projection of growth around 2.2% in 2017 and 2.4% in 2018, while the Euro Zone (ZE) would expand 1.7% in 2017 and 1.5% in 2018. On the other On the other hand, the US inflation rate would reach 2.5% and 2.3%, respectively, during those years, while in the ZE inflation rates of 1.6% and 1.4% are expected, below the Bank's 2.0% target. European Central (ECB). The macroeconomic conditions in the EZ have led the ECB to maintain an expansive monetary policy stance. As a result, the interest rate differential between the US and the ZE has increased, helping to strengthen the dollar in international markets.

In the case of Latin America, Consensus Forecast projects a real product expansion of 1.6% in 2017 and 2.6% in 2018. This growth is consistent with the fact that the countries of the region that are net exporters of commodities would benefit from higher prices of primary goods in international markets.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity continues to expand above its potential, observing a tendency to gradually converge to this level in the medium term. As of March, the Monthly Indicator of Economic Activity (IMAE) grows in line with the projections of the Monetary Program. Credit to the private sector in national currency expanded at an annual rate of around 10.0% at the end of April, consistent with the estimated nominal GDP growth rate.

On the fiscal policy side, public spending has moderated and is evolving according to the provisions of the 2017 budget. Regarding external accounts, the current account deficit closed 2016 at 1.4% of GDP, allowing a significant accumulation of international reserves and facilitating the maintenance of the relative stability of the exchange rate.

The BCRD reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target and maintain macroeconomic stability. In that sense, it will continue to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to adopt the necessary measures against possible risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting in April 2018, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.25% per annum.

The decision to leave the reference rate unchanged was based on the review of the balance of risks around inflation forecasts, as well as on the analysis of the main national macroeconomic indicators, the relevant international environment, market expectations and medium-term projections of this set of variables. Inflation for the month of March 2018 was 0.37%, which is why cumulative inflation in the first quarter of the year reached 0.55% and year-on-year inflation rose to 3.91%. Likewise, core inflation, linked to monetary conditions, was placed at 2.57% year-on-year. The forecasts indicate that inflation would remain within the target range of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0% established in the Monetary Program in the monetary policy horizon.

In the international environment, the global economic outlook remains dynamic, led by the growth of the industrialized economies. In fact, at the recent spring meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, more favorable global economic prospects were presented, highlighting that this is the greatest dynamism exhibited since 2011, amid favorable financial conditions and balanced risks. Indeed, according to its most recent report on the prospects of the world economy (WEO), the IMF forecasts a 3.9% growth for the world economy, both in 2018 and 2019. Among the developed economies, The IMF report highlights the growth projection of the United States of America (USA) with expansions of 2.9% in 2018 and 2.7% in 2019, followed by growth forecast for the Euro Zone (ZE) of 2.4% and 2.0% during those years. In the case of Latin America (AL), the IMF's growth outlook points to an expansion of 2.0% for 2018 and 2.8% for 2019. Only Venezuela would remain in recession during the projection period.

In terms of inflation, pressures on prices would remain moderate in advanced economies, with rates estimated at 2.5% in 2018 and 2.4% in 2019 for the US and 1.5% and 1.6% in those years for the EZ. In Latin America, average inflation, excluding Venezuela, would close the year at around 5.9%, according to Consensus Forecast.

As a result of better international economic performance, among other factors, prices of primary goods, mainly oil, have maintained their upward trend in the first half of the year. In that sense, the average price of a barrel of oil is around US $ 64 so far this year and it is expected to be gradually reduced, converging to about US $ 60 / barrel at the end of 2018.

In the domestic context, economic activity continues to evolve favorably in the short term. Taking into account the evolution of the Monthly Indicator of Economic Activity during the first two months of the year, the real product would expand above its potential in the first quarter, in a favorable international context and a domestic environment where the effects of the monetary stimulus remain of last year. In this regard, loans to the private sector in local currency grew around 13.5% year-on-year to the month of April, while monetary aggregates presented growth rates consistent with this credit expansion.

On the fiscal policy side, government revenues have remained above the amount budgeted during the first four months of the year, improving the outlook for compliance with the fiscal deficit target of 2.2% of GDP established in the 2018. In the external sector, dynamism continues in foreign exchange generating activities, such as tourism, remittances and foreign direct investment, which facilitates the relative stability of the foreign exchange market and the strengthening of international reserves.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy aimed at achieving the inflation target and maintaining macroeconomic stability. In this sense, it will continue to monitor the evolution of the world economy, as well as the main risks in the domestic context, in order to adopt the necessary measures in the face of possible effects on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
BCRD keeps its monetary policy rate at 5.50% per year
At its monetary policy meeting in April 2019, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.50% per annum.

The decision to leave the benchmark rate unchanged is based on detailed risk balance analysis for inflation forecasts, including information from international and domestic macroeconomic indicators, market expectations and medium-term projections. Inflation for march 2019 was 0.65%, so cumulative inflation in the first three months of the year stood at 0.86%. On the other hand, year-on-year inflation stood at 1.47% in March, while underlying inflation, which excludes prices for the most volatile components, stood at 2.15%. The BCRD's forecasting system and market expectations indicate that overall inflation would remain low, gradually approaching the centre of the target range of 4.0% - 1.0% over the two-year monetary policy horizon.

In the international environment, trade war in larger economies, coupled with geopolitical tensions and increased uncertainty in international financial markets, led to a downward revision of global growth. In this regard, Consensus Forecast estimated that the world economy would grow 2.7% in 2019 and 2.8% by 2020. The performance of advanced economies continues to be boosted by the United States of America, expanding by 3.2% during the first quarter of 2019. However, signs of a gradual slowdown in the US persist, projecting growth of 2.4% in 2019 and 2.0% by 2020. This context of lower growth in the U.S., coupled with low inflationary pressures led to a pause in the Federal Reserve's monetary normalization. Moreover, market analyst projections point to a possible reduction in the EDF's monetary policy rate this year.

On the other hand, in the face of a moderation in the growth of large economies such as France, Germany and Italy, the growth prospects for the Eurozone (EEG) continue to be downwards. Consensus Forecast estimates expansions of 1.1% and 1.3% for 2019 and 2020, respectively. The projections also indicate that ZE inflation would remain below its target for years to come. In this way, the European Central Bank would exhibit a more expansive-than-expected monetary policy stance by keeping its benchmark interest rate unchanged and through new programmes to stimulate the channeling of credit to the private sector through financial institutions. In this regard, international financial conditions would remain favourable for emerging economies.

In Latin America, growth forecasts have also been revised downwards by 1.6% for 2019 and recovering to 2.5% by 2020. Within the region, economies contrast with strong macroeconomic fundamentals with those that would remain in recession such as Venezuela, Argentina and Nicaragua, while other major economies in the region such as Brazil, Mexico, Ecuador and Uruguay would grow below 2.0% this year.

In terms of raw materials, the price of oil has shown a gradual upward trend since the beginning of the year associated with lower supply in the face of production cuts by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) and economic sanctions on oil-producing countries such as Iran and Venezuela. The average price of Texas Intermediate Oil (WTI) barrel is expected to be around $60.0 this year, in line with the National Budget.

In the domestic context, the Monthly Economic Activity Indicator (IMAE) notes that the Dominican economy continues to grow above its potential, with a year-on-year expansion of 5.9% in the January-February period of this year, driven mainly by investment and private consumption. The dynamism of domestic demand, coupled with favourable monetary conditions, has contributed to the continued growth of credit to the private sector in national currency at year-on-year rates of around 10.0%.

With regard to fiscal policy, there is a balanced balance sheet of the Non-Financial Public Sector in the first two months of the year, with a primary surplus expected to be maintained during 2019, as envisaged in the National Budget. In the external sector, foreign exchange-generating activities maintain remarkable dynamism, highlighting tourism, remittances and foreign direct investment; which has contributed to the relative stability of the exchange rate and facilitating the accumulation of international reserves.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic remains attentive to the evolution of international financial conditions and the dynamics of the price of oil at a global level, as well as the potential impact of climate phenomena on the domestic economy, being prepared to react in a timely manner to any factor that may generate inflationary diversions. In this regard, the issuing body reaffirms its commitment to driving monetary policy towards the achievement of its inflation target and the smooth functioning of the financial and payment systems, thus contributing to the maintenance of macroeconomic stability.
BCRD keeps its monetary policy rate at 3.50% per year

At its monetary policy meeting in April 2020, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 3.50% per annum. In addition, the interest rate for the permanent ease of expansion (Repos to 1 day) remains at 4.50% per annum, while the interest rate on paid deposits (Overnight) stands at 2.50% per annum.

The decision on the benchmark rate is based on a comprehensive analysis of the impact of the current uncertainty on macroeconomic stability and future inflation developments. In this sense, the monthly inflation of March was -0.52 %, while the inflation accumulated during the first three months of the year was -0.32%. On the other hand, year-on-year inflation, i.e. from March 2019 to March 2020, moderated to 2.45%, below the target range of 4.0% to 1.0%, while the underlying inflation, reflecting monetary conditions, reached 2.67%. Moving forward, the BCRD forecasting system indicates that inflation would remain below the lower bound of the target range for the remainder of 2020. Low inflationary pressures give the BCRD greater degrees of freedom to continue reacting in a timely manner to the adverse impact of COVID-19 on the Dominican economy, if necessary.

In the international environment, the accelerated spread of coronavirus has forced strong containment measures, which would have a significant negative impact on global economic activity. As a result, the International Monetary Fund (IMF), in its Report World Economic Outlook published in April, decreased global growth projections from 2.9% in 2019 to -3.0% in 2020. In response to the deterioration in global growth, central banks around the world have taken monetary easing and liquidity provision measures to support their countries' domestic demands.

In the United States of America (USA), the IMF projects that economic activity would contract this year, ranging from an expansion of 2.3% in 2019 to -5.9% by 2020. Indeed, preliminary estimates indicate that growth in the U.S. economy moderated to 0.3% year-on-year during the first quarter, influenced by a fall in consumption and private investment. In this context of uncertainty, high stock market volatility and low inflationary pressures, the Federal Reserve (Fed) reduced the federal funds rate by 150 basis points during the month of March, placing it in the range of 0% - 0.25%. In addition, the Fed expanded its liquidity provision programs to the financial system through Repos to varying terms of up to 90 days, purchases on the secondary market of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities and credit channeling programs for small and medium-sized enterprises through financial institutions.

As for the Euro Zone, the IMF projects that COVID-19 will cause an even greater contraction in this bloc of countries, moving from 1.2% growth in 2019 to -7.5% by 2020. In response to the impact of coronavirus, the European Central Bank keeps the rate of short-term deposits (Overnight) at -0.50% per annum, while extending the liquidity provision programme for private credit pipeline through financial institutions and expanding the purchase of public and private securities on the secondary market.

On the other hand, Latin America, which was already facing a weakened economic situation, has been simultaneously affected by the impact of coronavirus and falling commodity prices, causing a reduction in the regional growth outlook to -5.2% by 2020. In this context, the central banks of Brazil, Chile, Mexico, Colombia, Peru, Guatemala, Honduras and Costa Rica have lowered their interest rates this year, as well as taking additional liquidity provision measures through financial institutions.

In relation to raw materials, a substantial reduction in the price of Texas intermediate oil has been observed due to a combination of low demand and increased inventories, placing below $15 a barrel at the end of April. By contrast, the price of gold has increased, ranking around $1,700 per troy ounce, when it is used as a value haven in an environment of high uncertainty. The price dynamics of primary goods implies an improvement in terms of trade for the Dominican Republic which is reflected in a decrease in the oil turnover and an increase in gold exports, which along with the flow of remittances received during the first quarter of the year exceeding US$1.7 billion and the growth of domestic and free zone exports , partially offset the impact of COVID-19 on the external sector.

Importantly, at the time of the pandemic containment measures in the Dominican Republic, the economy was in a favourable cyclical position, characterized by economic growth around potential and low inflationary pressures, giving it the flexibility to accommodate this adverse shock through the adoption of expansive monetary measures aimed at boosting domestic demand. Indeed, preliminary information from the Monthly Economic Activity Index (IMAE) indicates a marked slowdown during the month of March in relation to the pace of expansion observed in January and February, although the economy would not be recording negative growth during the first quarter of the year in the face of the impact of COVID-19.

In this context, the Central Bank has adopted in March and April a set of monetary and financial measures aimed at preserving economic stability and mitigating the effects of coronavirus through increased financing for productive sectors and households at lower interest rates. In particular, of the total RD$100 billion that has been made available to financial intermediation entities, some RD$50 billion have been channelled through different facilities. Of this amount, some RD$10 billion correspond to private loans granted through the release of resources from the legal lace and some RD$40 billion to provision liquidity to financial intermediation entities through Repos up to 90 days.

It is emphasized that, even under current conditions of high uncertainty, legal lace resources are being channelled at a faster rate than all previous occasions when this monetary policy instrument has been used. In addition, there has also been a significant reduction of around 300 basis points in interest rates on loans granted by multiple banks during the month of April and greater dynamism in monetary aggregates.

These favourable monetary conditions have contributed to an acceleration of credit to the private sector expanding by around 13% year-on-year, highlighting the channelling of loans to the Manufacturing, Hotels and Restaurants, Construction and Commerce sectors. The dynamism of private credit increases access to working capital for sectors currently operating at full capacity and provides greater liquidity to those activities suspended by the pandemic. It is important to note that the Central Bank has the necessary space to continue to support the productive sectors and households, once the sanitary conditions allow for a process of gradual normalization of the economy, and facilitate a rapid recovery in domestic demand.

On the other hand, it should be noted that the approval of the disbursement of some US$650 million as emergency financial assistance by the IMF, equivalent to 100% of the country's share in this multilateral body, will help the Dominican government continue to face the challenges posed by COVID-19. Access to these resources, together with the Central Bank's $622 million foreign currency liquidity provision measures and the Central Bank's high levels of international reserves, will help maintain relative exchange rate stability in the face of a convulsing international environment.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to drive monetary policy towards achieving its inflation target and the smooth functioning of financial and payment systems, thus contributing to the maintenance of macroeconomic stability. In this regard, the institution will continue to monitor the impact of the coronavirus on the Dominican economy, being prepared to continue reacting in a timely manner to factors that may lead to deviations from the inflation target and affect economic growth.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic, at its Monetary Policy Meeting of May 2012 decided, effective June 1, to reduce its Monetary Policy Interest Rate (Overnight) by 75 basis points, from 6.75% to 6.0% per annum. At the same time, it decided to reduce the Lombard Rate by 100 basis points, from 9.0% to 8.0% annually. With this decision, the policy rate corridor narrows.

The decision regarding the benchmark interest rate is based on the fact that in a passive scenario, projections point to an inflation rate below the lower limit of the target for this year. In fact, in the month of April, the interannual rate of inflation was 4.0%, below the goal that this year was established at 5.5% <U+00B1> 1%. Core interannual inflation, which is associated with monetary inflationary pressures, fell to 3.7%, its lowest level in the last two years. The forecast models indicate that no significant inflationary pressures are expected in the monetary policy horizon.

In the external context, the growth of the US economy continues to be moderate, while increasing uncertainty about how the European Union would solve its financial and fiscal sustainability problems, strengthening the prospects for weak economic growth for that area. On the other hand, in recent months emerging economies have shown a more modest performance than anticipated, although growth expectations remain positive, particularly in emerging Asia and Latin America. The moderation in global economic activity and the greater uncertainty about the European crisis have contributed to reversing the upward trend observed in the prices of raw materials at the beginning of the year. In that sense, the international price of oil has been reduced since last March, falling below the forecasts of the Economic Consensus and the IMF for the current year.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity continues to show a moderate performance, growing around 4% during the first quarter of the year, a rate below its potential. The current levels of interest rates and expectations created by the electoral cycle have slowed the rate of growth of credit to the private sector in national currency, which has been below the nominal GDP growth forecast for the current year. Despite the external situation, the performance of the export sector continues to improve, while the growth of imports has moderated and a higher-than-expected increase in foreign direct investment is projected. These factors help to relieve pressures on external accounts. Regarding market inflation expectations, economic surveys show a more positive scenario with inflation forecasts in the target range, both for 2012 and 2013.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve the inflation target of 5.5% <U+00B1> 1% for 2012, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation in order to react in a timely manner to risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic, in its Monetary Policy Meeting of May 2013, decided to reduce its Monetary Policy Interest Rate (MPR) from 5.00% to 4.25%. . This is the first reduction of the MPR since August 2012. According to the new short-term liquidity management scheme of the Central Bank, the interest rates of permanent expansion and monetary contraction facilities will decrease to 6.25% and 2.25% annual, respectively.

The decision on the benchmark interest rate takes into account that the forecast models indicate that there will be no major inflationary pressures in the coming months and no deviations from inflation are expected with respect to its target in the monetary policy horizon. On the other hand, production is below its potential capacity and during the quarter January-March recorded a growth rate below the average of recent years, as a result of the weakness that domestic demand has been showing. Macroeconomic models indicate that, if measures are not taken, production will remain below its potential until the end of 2014. Market inflation expectations are located around the objective of the Monetary Program.

In terms of price data, in April the monthly inflation rate was -0.06%, while in accumulated terms it reached 1.9% in the first four months of the year. The year-on-year inflation rate fell to 4.9% in April, influenced by the negative inflation of that month. Additionally, the interannual core inflation stood at 5.0%, also presenting a downward trend with respect to the previous month.

In the external context, the Euro Zone remains in recession, registering a fall in its economic activity of 0.8% in the first quarter of the year. The United States of America, on the other hand, achieved 2.5% growth in the same period, which confirms the moderate recovery trend that this economy has been exhibiting since the end of 2011. According to the Consensus Forecast, the economies of the Euro Zone and The US would present growth of around -0.5% and 1.9% at the end of the year, respectively. In Japan, the recent measures of monetary expansion have brought optimism in that economy, but China and other important emerging economies have shown signs of slowdown, reflecting the latter in a fall in the prices of primary goods, especially minerals. International financial conditions have improved, despite the fragility of the fiscal situation in some industrialized economies.

In the domestic sphere, the economic activity measured by the Real Gross Domestic Product grew 0.3% in the first quarter, reflecting a notable weakness in domestic demand and an excess supply of goods and services. However, credit to the private sector in national currency would be accelerating, influenced by the recent measures to liberalize reserve requirements, which has allowed year-on-year growth of private loans in national currency of over 8% in May. The expansion of private credit indicated is in line with the projection of nominal GDP growth for the year end of 8.2%. As for the external sector, exports would be growing due to the increase in mining exports. This, combined with the drop in imports of goods and services and the reduction in the value of the oil bill, would allow an improvement in the current account of the balance of payments by the end of the year.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target. At the same time, it will continue to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation in order to adopt, if necessary, new measures that contribute to boost credit and stimulate domestic demand, provided that they do not jeopardize price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its May 2014 monetary policy meeting, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic decided to keep the monetary policy interest rate unchanged at 6.25% per annum.

The decision regarding the reference rate took into account the balance of risks around the inflation projections, as well as market expectations on the main macroeconomic variables. In April, the interannual rate of inflation amounted to 3.49%, placing itself at the lower end of the target range for 2014 of 4.5% <U+00B1> 1%. Accumulated inflation in the first four months of the year was 1.53%. On the other hand, core interannual inflation, which is related to monetary conditions, was 3.39% at the end of April.

In the external sphere, the recovery prospects of the developed economies and a modest performance of the developing countries remain. However, in the face of extreme weather conditions, the United States of America revised its inter-annual growth from the first quarter downwards from 2.3% to 2.0%. Regarding the growth forecast for the end of the year, Consensus Forecast modified its estimate from 2.7% to 2.5%. On the other hand, the Euro Zone shows a growth of 0.9% in the first quarter, driven by a 2.3% expansion of the German economy. Low inflationary pressures in industrialized countries anticipate the maintenance of low international interest rates for an extended period, while the financial conditions faced by emerging economies tend to improve. The prices of primary goods, particularly oil and food, have remained relatively stable in the last month.

In the domestic sphere, the trend-cycle of the Monthly Indicator of Economic Activity expanded by around 6.0% for the month of April, indicating that, if this trend continues, the dynamics of national production could exceed growth projections. At the same time, monetary conditions have improved during the first part of the year. While the monetary aggregates present interannual growth rates of around 10% at the end of May, the financial entities maintain sufficient liquidity to continue channeling resources to the productive sectors. Credit to the private sector in national currency grew around 13.5% year-to-year at the end of May. It is expected that this healthy rate of expansion in private loans will be maintained for the rest of the year in the face of favorable monetary conditions, which, in an environment of growth and inflation projections in the target range, suggests a neutral stance on monetary policy. In the area of ??fiscal accounts, public investment has been reactivated in line with the provisions of the National Budget, while fiscal revenues remain above the estimate. Regarding the external sector, the positive result of the global balance of payments, driven by a current account surplus in the first quarter of the year, anticipates low pressures in the foreign exchange market.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation in order to take the necessary measures against risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.

At its monetary policy meeting in May 2015, the Central Bank (BCRD) decided to reduce its monetary policy interest rate (MPR) for the third consecutive month. On this occasion, it decreased by 25 basis points, from 5.25% to 5.00% per annum, as of June 1, 2015. With this decision, the cumulative reduction of the MPR this year is 125 basis points.

According to the BCRD short-term liquidity management scheme, the rate of paid deposits (overnight) is reduced from 3.75% to 3.50% per year and the rate of expansion facilities (repos) decreases from 6.75% to 6.50% per annum .

The decision to reduce the reference rate was adopted after analyzing the national macroeconomic panorama, especially the balance of risks around the inflation projections, as well as the evolution of the relevant international environment and its impact on market and economic expectations. Dominican It is expected that the policy decision will favorably affect economic growth without putting the inflation target at risk in the policy horizon.

The interannual inflation rate in April stood at -0.04%, while the accumulated inflation so far this year stood at -0.09%. Additionally, core inflation, related to the monetary conditions of the economy, fell in April to 2.37% year-on-year. The projections continue indicating that inflation would remain below the lower limit of the goal for the current year of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0%, during 2015.

Externally, the most recent data on the world economy show little change since last month. The economies of developed countries maintain their recovery process. Consensus Forecast projects growth for the United States of America (USA) around 2.5% in 2015 and 2.8% in 2016, converging the unemployment rate in the coming months to its full employment level of 5.25%. On the other hand, an expansion is foreseen for the Euro Zone of 1.5% in the current year and 1.8% next year.

Latin America continues to grow well below its historical average and some of the largest economies, such as Brazil, Argentina and Venezuela, are in recession. According to Consensus Forecast, the region's growth would reach 0.4% in 2015. After several months of decline, oil prices have shown a slight upturn in the last month, although they still remain at levels lower than last year. The US dollar maintains a significant degree of appreciation in interannual terms in the international exchange markets.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity grew 6.5% in real terms during the first quarter of the year, lower than the rate of 8.1% in the same period last year. Also, in the Financial System, the annual growth rate of credit to the private sector in national currency was around 12.0% in May, below the 15.5% expansion rate, reached at the end of last year. . On the fiscal policy side, the budgetary execution of the first quarter presents a surplus balance and suggests that a primary surplus would be obtained by the end of 2015. Additionally, the current account of the balance of payments is projected to register a deficit around to 2.0% of GDP by the end of the year. This level is lower than its historical average and lower than the 3.2% of GDP registered in 2014, which would facilitate relative stability in the foreign exchange market and the accumulation of international reserves over and above what is planned in the Monetary Program.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to implement monetary policy aimed at achieving its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to take the necessary measures against risks to the stability of the economy. prices and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting in May 2016, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic decided to maintain the monetary policy rate (MPR) at 5.0% per annum.

The decision regarding the reference rate took into account the balance of risks around inflation forecasts, market expectations, as well as the recent evolution of the main macroeconomic variables. In April, the interannual rate of inflation was 1.75%, this variable remaining below the lower end of the target range of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1% for 2016. The accumulated inflation in the first four months of the year is - 0.67%, while core interannual inflation, which is related to monetary conditions, was 1.51% at the close of the fourth month of the year.

In the external sphere, the outlook for the world economy, according to the Consensus Forecast, points to a growth of 2.4% in 2016 and 2.8% in 2017. In the United States of America (USA), however, Consensus's growth forecast it was adjusted to fall from 2.0% to 1.8% for the current year 2016, expecting a recovery of the economy with an expansion of 2.3% in 2017. In light of these events, the implicit probability of an increase in the monetary policy rate of the FED has increased, judging by the future contracts of the market, reason why a possible increase in the next months is expected. Although a decision of this type could affect the performance of bond placements in international markets, it would also generate an appreciation of the dollar that could cause a further reduction in oil prices. These possible impacts of an increase in the FDM of the FED have, to a large extent, been internalized by the market. In that sense, the eventual increase in the FED's rates should not have a significant short-term effect on the Dominican economy.

Regarding the economies of other regions of the world, Consensus Forecast maintained its projection of growth for the Euro Zone, which implies that the economy would expand around 1.6%, both in 2016 and in 2017. On the other hand, Latin America (AL) would present a contraction in its gross domestic production of -0.6% in 2016, mainly due to the recession experienced by countries such as Venezuela (-8.6%), Brazil (-3.7%), Ecuador (-1.7%) and Argentina ( -1.1%). It should be noted that other important economies of the region would have positive growth, but below the average of the last 5 years. Such is the case of economies such as Mexico (2.4%), Chile (1.8%), Colombia (2.4%), Costa Rica (3.6%) and Uruguay (1.3%). It is expected that by 2017, the average growth of the LA economies will become positive, reaching an expansion of around 2.0%.

The prices of primary goods, particularly that of some commodities of importance in foreign trade transactions in the Dominican Republic, have been exhibiting an upward trend in the last two months. In that sense, WTI oil has been close to US $ 50 a barrel, while gold has approached US $ 1,300 a troy ounce, a price higher than that contemplated in the 2016 National Budget.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity continues to show growth above its potential, with a preliminary record of the Monthly Indicator of Economic Activity (IMAE), a robust year-on-year expansion of 10.1% in the month of April. During the period January-April, the accumulated growth of the IMAE was 7.1%, compared to the same period last year. It is important to note that all sectors of the economy posted positive year-on-year growth in April, with construction (36.2), financial services (13.3%), local manufacturing (11.7%), commerce (11.1%) and the recovery of the sector standing out. agriculture (6.0%), among others.

In the financial sector, credit to the private sector grew around 13.8% in May and is expected to expand at a rate close to 12.0% at the end of the year. With regard to fiscal policy, the Government is expected to comply with the forecast budget deficit for the end of the year at around 2.3% of GDP. In turn, in the external sector, the current account deficit would be around 1.9% of GDP by the end of the year. In this context, the exchange market would remain relatively stable and allow a continuous accumulation of international reserves.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation in order to take the necessary measures against risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting in May 2017, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.75% per annum.

The decision regarding the reference rate resulted from a comprehensive analysis of the balance of risks around the inflation projections including the main national macroeconomic indicators, market expectations and the relevant international environment for the Dominican economy.

The price data for the month of April show that the accumulated inflation for the first four months of the year was 1.11%. In turn, in annual terms, April inflation reached 3.51%, remaining within the target range of 4% <U+00B1> 1% established in the Monetary Program. On the other hand, core inflation, related to monetary conditions, amounted to 2.16%. According to the most recent projections, inflation would remain within the target range in the policy horizon.

In the international context, the economy of the United States of America (USA) would be growing around 2.1% in 2017 and 2.4% in 2018, according to Consensus Forecast. Also, inflation would be 2.4% and 2.2% in 2017 and 2018, respectively. The market expects to continue the process of normalization of monetary policy with further rate increases, by the FED, in the coming months. On the other hand, in the Euro Zone (ZE) economic activity would continue to expand around the potential, registering annual rates of 1.7% in 2017 and 1.6% in 2018. Inflation in this block of countries would remain below the target of 2.0% of the European Central Bank (ECB), reaching 1.6% and 1.4% in 2017 and 2018, respectively.

For Latin America, the Consensus Forecast contemplates an exit from the recession in 2017, leaving Venezuela as the only country that would register a fall in its economic activity during the current year. The projections indicate that the region would expand by 1.6% this year and 2.6% by 2018, in the face of more favorable terms of trade. On the other hand, oil prices remain around US $ 50 per barrel, and current prospects do not contemplate significant fluctuations in the price of this mineral.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity grew 5.2% in the first quarter of the year, gradually approaching its potential. Preliminary information of the Monthly Indicator of Economic Activity (IMAE) show a moderate growth in the month of April, due to the intense rains registered in some regions of the country, as well as for the purposes of statistical comparability given the high dynamism shown by the economy in April of 2016. Despite this moderation, a growth in the range of 5.0-5.5% is projected for this year, in line with that contemplated in the Monetary Program. Credit to the private sector in national currency increased at an annual rate of around 10.5% in May, consistent with the rate of expansion of economic activity in nominal terms.

On the fiscal side, budget execution indicates a policy in line with the goals established in the government's financial plan. In that sense, as of April, government spending showed a decrease with respect to the level reached in the same period last year. This behavior, together with a significant improvement in revenues in May, points to the government meeting its deficit target of 2.3% of GDP for 2017, which implies a primary surplus of 0.8% of GDP. Regarding external accounts, foreign exchange generating activities, such as tourism and remittances, maintain a good performance, contributing to the strengthening of international reserves and facilitating the maintenance of the relative stability of the exchange rate.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target and to maintain macroeconomic stability. In that sense, it will continue to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to adopt the necessary measures against possible risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting in May 2018, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.25% per annum.

The decision to leave the reference rate unchanged was based on an exhaustive analysis of the risk balance for inflation, the main national macroeconomic indicators, the relevant international environment, market expectations and medium-term projections.

Accumulated inflation during the first four months of the year was 0.95%, after observing in April a monthly variation of 0.40% in the consumer price index. In terms of twelve months, that is, from April 2018 to April 2017, the inflation rate stood at 4.05%, around the center of the target range of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0% established in the Monetary Program.

Likewise, core inflation, linked to monetary conditions, was placed at 2.73% year-on-year. Forecasts indicate that inflation would remain within the target range in the two-year monetary policy horizon.

In the international environment, the economic outlook continues to be characterized by the growth of world production. In that sense, Consensus Forecasts projects an expansion of the global economy of 3.3% in 2018 and 3.2% in 2019, under the leadership of the industrialized countries and some emerging economies. However, while the United States of America (USA) maintains a high economic dynamism, growth in the Euro Zone and in Japan tends to moderate.

In this context, the markets anticipate that the process of rising interest rates in the US will continue, while maintaining an expansive monetary policy stance in the rest of the advanced economies. As a result of the macroeconomic behavior and the differences in monetary positions in the US and the ZE, a tendency of the dollar to appreciate in international markets is expected.

This behavior of the US currency, together with upward pressure on the price of oil, could provoke a change in the monetary policy stance in some emerging economies through increases in their monetary policy interest rates.

Under this scenario, according to Consensus, the US economy would grow 2.8% in 2018 and 2.6% in 2019, while the economy of the Euro Zone would expand by 2.3% and 1.9%, during those years, respectively.

On the other hand, in the emerging world, the BRICS economies (Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa) continue to grow, led by India, which is expanding at a rate higher than 7.0% so far this year and by China, which registered an increase in its real production of 6.8% in the first quarter.

Brazil, the Latin American giant, would be growing 2.5% in 2018 and 2.9% in 2019. In the case of Latin America as a region, Consensus presents growth prospects of 2.7% for 2018 and 3.0% for 2019, excluding Venezuela that it would continue in recession.

In the domestic context, economic activity continues to evolve favorably, as can be observed in the trajectory of the monthly indicator of economic activity (IMAE). In effect, the IMAE grew 7.5% in year-on-year terms in the month of April and 6.7% during the first four months of the year.

At the same time, the trend-cycle component of the IMAE expands 6.6% in April, showing that the economy will continue to grow above its potential. This dynamism was the result, to a large extent, of the monetary stimulus provided last year by the reduction in the monetary policy rate and in the legal reserve.

As a result of these measures, loans to the private sector in local currency continue to grow about 13% year-on-year to the month of May, while monetary aggregates present growth rates above nominal GDP expansion.

On the fiscal sector side, income from collections has remained consistently above the budgeted amount during the five months of this year. If this trend continues, fiscal policy would achieve the deficit target of -2.2% of GDP, established in the 2018 Budget.

In the external sector, the increase in oil prices is being compensated by a greater dynamism in foreign exchange generating activities, such as tourism, remittances, exports of goods and foreign direct investment, which contributes to the maintenance of the relative stability of the exchange rate and the strengthening of international reserves.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy aimed at achieving the inflation target and maintaining macroeconomic stability. In this sense, it will continue to monitor the evolution of the world economy, as well as the main risks in the domestic context, in order to adopt the necessary measures in the face of possible effects on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
BCRD keeps its monetary policy rate at 5.50% per year
At its monetary policy meeting in May 2019, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.50% per annum.

The decision to keep the benchmark rate unchanged is based on detailed analysis of the risk balance against inflation forecasts, including information from international and domestic macroeconomic indicators, market expectations and medium-term projections. April's monthly inflation was 0.53%, while cumulative inflation in the first four months of the year reached 1.39%. On the other hand, year-on-year inflation stood at 1.61%, while underlying inflation, reflecting monetary conditions, moderated to 2.07% in April. The BCRD forecasting system indicates that inflation would remain until the end of 2019 below the lower bound of the target range of 4.0% x 1.0%, converging at the centre of the target by 2020.

The international environment has become more volatile, increasing uncertainty factors, including the escalation of trade disputes between major economies, the lack of agreement around the UK's exit from the European Union (Brexit) and the persistence of socio-political tensions in some emerging economies. Against this complex scenario, the growth outlook for the global economy has been revised downwards, estimated at 2.8% for 2019 and 2.9% by 2020, according to Consensus Forecasts.

The performance of advanced economies continues to be driven by the United States of America,s.), although current indicators point to a potential slowdown for this economy in the medium term. Indeed, Consensus's projections indicate potential moderation in U.S. growth from 2.9% in 2018 to 2.6% in 2019 and 1.9% in 2020. Considering the prospects for a likely deterioration in economic activity, the Federal Reserve is expected to not make increases in its benchmark interest rate for the remainder of 2019, while the market expects at least a reduction in US interest rates by the end of this year.

Also, in the face of slowing growth in the major euro zone economies (EES), growth prospects for this bloc remain low, with expansions estimated to be 1.1% in 2019 and 1.3% by 2020, according to Consensus. In view of this scenario, the European Central Bank has announced that it would maintain an expansive monetary policy stance at least until the end of 2019, while implementing a new liquidity provision programme to stimulate the private sector's lending pipeline through financial institutions.

In Latin America, growth forecasts were revised downwards, with an expansion of 1.3% in 2019. It is important to note that the behavior within the region is heterogeneous. On the one hand, Venezuela, Argentina and Nicaragua would remain in recession, while the two largest economies, Brazil and Mexico, are projected to grow below 1.5%. On the other hand, a group of economies would continue to grow with strong macroeconomic fundamentals, such as the Dominican Republic, Panama, Peru and Chile.

In relation to raw materials, the price of oil has shown a downward trend recently, influenced by a moderation in global demand and concerns about trade tensions. Indeed, the price of Texas intermediate crude oil (WTI) fell below $55.0 a barrel at the end of May, below the level stipulated in the National Budget of $60.0 a barrel.

In the domestic context, credit to the private sector has gradually slowed its pace of expansion, rising by 9.2% year-on-year at the end of May. In this sense, the recent action announced by the Monetary Board to release more than RD$29 billion of resources from the legal loophole, in an environment of low inflationary pressures, will contribute to boosting credit and growing the economy at the pace stipulated in the Monetary Programme of around 5.5%.

With regard to fiscal policy, a balanced balance of the non-financial public sector is observed during the first months of the year, with a waiting for a primary surplus to be maintained during 2019, as envisaged in the National Budget. In the external sector, foreign exchange-generating activities such as tourism, remittances and foreign direct investment perform well, contributing to relative exchange rate stability and facilitating greater accumulation of international reserves.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic continues to monitor the moderation of the world economy and the uncertainty factors of the international environment, as well as its potential impact on the performance of domestic demand, being prepared to react in a timely manner to factors that may lead to deviations from the monetary agenda targets.
BCRD keeps its monetary policy rate at 3.50% per year

At its monetary policy meeting in May 2020, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 3.50% per annum. In addition, the interest rate for the permanent ease of expansion (Repos to 1 day) remains at 4.50% per annum, while the interest rate on paid deposits (Overnight) stands at 2.50% per year.

The decision on the benchmark rate is based on a comprehensive analysis of the impact of the current uncertainty on macroeconomic stability and future inflation developments. In this sense, April's monthly inflation was -0.82%, while cumulative inflation during the first four months of the year was -1.14%. On the other hand, year-on-year inflation, i.e. from April 2019 to April 2020, was moderated to 1.07%, below the target range of 4.0% to 1.0%, while the underlying inflation, reflecting monetary conditions, reached 2.75%. Moving forward, the BCRD forecasting system indicates that inflation would remain below the lower bound of the target range for the remainder of 2020. Low inflationary pressures give the BCRD greater degrees of freedom to continue reacting in a timely manner to the adverse impact of COVID-19 on the Dominican economy, if necessary.

In the international environment, high uncertainty prevails, even though, in those economies that have passed the most critical phases of the pandemic, containment measures that forced the cessation of productive activities and which have widened economic growth are beginning to be lifted. In this regard, Consensus Forecasts (CFC), which brings together leading analyst firms that make international projections, significantly reduced global growth projections from 2.5% in 2019 to -4.1% in 2020. In response to the weakening of global growth, central banks around the world continue to implement monetary easing and liquidity provision measures to support their countries' domestic demands.In the United States of America (USA), Consensus Forecasts projects that economic activity would contract this year, moving from an expansion of 2.3% in 2019 to -5.4% by 2020. Indeed, growth in the U.S. economy moderated to 0.2% year-on-year during the first quarter, while in April the unemployment rate stood at 14.7%, the highest since the Great Depression of 1929. In addition, different indicators of consumption and industrial production suggest that the U.S. economy would show further deterioration in the second quarter of this year. In this context of low growth, higher unemployment and lack of inflation, the Federal Reserve (Fed) has adopted a group of expansive measures, keeping at low levels its federal fund rate that is in the range of 0% - 0.25%, as well as the various quantitative easing programs injecting liquidity through Repos, purchases of public and private titles in the secondary market and credit channeling programs for micro small and medium-sized enterprises.

As for the Euro Area, Consensus Forecasts projects that COVID-19 will cause an even greater contraction in this bloc of countries, ranging from 1.2% growth in 2019 to -7.9% by 2020. In response to this difficult outlook, the European Central Bank (ECB) keeps the short-term deposit rate (Overnight) at -0.50% per annum, while easing the terms of the private credit channelling programme through financial institutions and expanded the programme for the purchase of public and private securities on the secondary market.

On the other hand, the high uncertainty caused by the pandemic has led to an increase in volatility in capital flows and affected the growth prospects of emerging economies, leading to a widespread depreciation of their currencies against the US dollar. In particular, Latin America, which was already facing a weakened economic situation, has been affected by falling commodity prices and a global tourism flow, causing a regional contraction of -5.9% by 2020. In this context, central banks in the region continue to implement liquidity provision and credit channeling programmes to the private sector in a widespread manner.

In relation to raw materials, the price of Texas intermediate oil (WTI) has shown a partial recovery in May, influenced by the production cut agreed between countries belonging to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) and its allies. Thus, the price of WTI was in May around US$30 a barrel, a level similar to the projection for the rest of the year. On the other hand, the price of gold remains high, around $1,700 per troy ounce, when it is used as a haven of value in a context of high uncertainty. The price dynamics of primary goods benefit the terms of trade for the Dominican Republic, which would partially offset, through lower oil bills and higher gold exports, the negative impact the pandemic has had on the external sector, particularly on tourism, remittances and exports as a result of the fall in the world economy.

Importantly, at the time of coVID-19 containment measures in the Dominican Republic, the economy was in a favourable cyclical position, characterized by growth around potential and low inflationary pressures. These strong macroeconomic fundamentals have given the flexibility to take expansive monetary measures to accommodate the adverse shock. Indeed, preliminary information from the Monthly Economic Activity Index (IMAE) indicates that economic activity slowed significantly in March relative to the rate of expansion observed in January and February, thus recording a 0.0% year-on-year change in the first quarter of 2020.

In this context, the Central Bank continues to implement a set of monetary and financial measures aimed at mitigating the effects of coronavirus through increased financing for productive sectors and households at lower interest rates. In particular, of the total RD$ 120 billion that have been made available to financial intermediation entities, some RD$ 64 billion have been channeled through different facilities, with some RD$56 billion being available to continue to support the productive activity and contribute to a rapid recovery in domestic demand during the rest of the year.

It is emphasized that, even under current conditions of high uncertainty, the resources provided by the BCRD are being channelled at a faster rate than all previous occasions when these monetary policy instruments have been used. As a result, there has been a significant reduction of about 300 basis points in interest rates on loans granted by multiple banks since the adoption of the measures and a greater dynamism in monetary aggregates.

In addition, favorable monetary conditions have contributed to an acceleration of credit to the private sector that expands at rates close to 14% year-on-year, highlighting the channelling of loans to the Manufacturing, Hotels and Restaurants, Trade and Construction sectors. The dynamism of private credit has increased access to working capital for sectors that have remained operating during the pandemic and provided greater liquidity to those activities that were suspended by confinement measures.

On the other hand, it should be noted that the disbursement of some US$651 million as emergency financial assistance by the IMF, together with the measures to provide liquidity in foreign currency of about US$ 622 million and the interventions in the foreign exchange market that have been made during this year for some US$2.2 billion, will contribute to maintaining the relative stability of the exchange rate in the face of a convulsing international environment. In addition, the central bank's high levels of International Reserves, equivalent to approximately 10% of GDP, are highlighted, so the institution reiterates that it has sufficient resources and tools to continue to support the foreign exchange market, so that all foreign exchange needs of economic actors and the general public are met.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to drive monetary policy towards achieving its inflation target and the smooth functioning of financial and payment systems, thus contributing to the maintenance of macroeconomic stability. In this regard, the institution will continue to monitor the impact of COVID-19 on the Dominican economy, being prepared to continue reacting in a timely manner to factors that could jeopardize the inflation target and affect macroeconomic stability.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic, in its Monthly Monetary Policy Meeting of June 2012, decided to maintain its Monetary Policy Interest Rate (Overnight) at 6.0% per annum. At the same time, it decided to leave the Lombard Rate unchanged at 8.0% per annum.

The decision not to vary the reference interest rate is based on the fact that the projections confirm that the inflation rate would continue around the lower limit of the target for the rest of the year. Indeed, in the month of May, the interannual inflation rate stood at 3.54%, below the target of 5.5% <U+00B1> 1% for this year 2012. The interannual core inflation, which is related to monetary conditions, reached 3.67. %, while accumulated inflation in the January-May period stood at 0.68%. The forecast models do not foresee significant inflationary pressures in the monetary policy horizon.

In the external context, in June, the Federal Reserve Bank of the United States adjusted its growth forecast downward, from a range of 2.2% -2.8% to a range of 1.9% -2.4%, at the same time it foresees a lower inflation and higher unemployment. On the other hand, the Eurozone maintains a recession scenario with growth projections of -0.4% according to consensus. International financial markets show an increase in risk aversion due to uncertainty about the debt and fiscal crisis in some countries of the European Union, mainly Greece and Spain. International prices of primary goods continue to show a downward trend, although they remain high with respect to their historical averages.

In the domestic sphere, the production and domestic demand indicators maintain a moderate trend and the projections indicate, in a passive scenario, that there would be idle production capacity so that the output gap would remain negative in the medium term. The growth forecasts for the end of the year point to a range of 4.0% -4.5%, in an environment of low inflationary pressures and relative stability of the exchange rate. Real interest rates remain positive which favors savings over consumption and investment spending, while the rate of growth of credit to the private sector has continued to moderate. The inflation expectations of the market are anchored around the goal, both for 2012 and for 2013.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve the inflation target of 5.5% <U+00B1> 1% for 2012, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation in order to react in a timely manner to risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.

Organizational Matters By unanimous vote, Simon Potter was selected to serve at the pleasure of the Committee as Manager, System Open Market Account, effective June 30, 2012, on the understanding that his selection was subject to being satisfactory to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Secretary<U+0092>s note: Advice subsequently was received that the selection of Mr. Potter as Manager was satisfactory to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. By unanimous vote, the Committee selected James J. McAndrews to serve as Associate Economist, effective June 30, 2012, until the selection of his successor at the first regularly scheduled meeting of the Committee in 2013. By unanimous vote, the Committee amended the FOMC Policy on External Communications of Federal Reserve System Staff to clarify some specific aspects of the policy.3 Discussion of Communications regarding Economic Projections Meeting participants discussed several possibilities for enhancing the clarity and transparency of the Committee<U+0092>s economic projections and their role in policy decisions and policy communications. In particular, participants noted that while the Summary of Economic Projections (SEP) provides information about their individual projections of key macroeconomic variables and about the path of monetary policy that each sees as appropriate and consistent with his or her projections, the SEP does not provide guidance about how those 3 The policy is available at www.federalreserve.gov/monetary policy/files/FOMC_ExtCommunicationStaff.pdf . diverse views come together in the Committee<U+0092>s collective judgment about the outlook and appropriate policy as expressed in its postmeeting statement. Many participants indicated that if it were possible to construct a quantitative economic projection and associated path of appropriate policy that reflected the collective judgment of the Committee, such a projection could potentially be helpful in clarifying how the outlook and policy decisions are related. Participants discussed examples of the economic and policy projections published by a number of foreign central banks. Participants generally indicated a willingness to explore adjustments to the SEP, while highlighting the importance of communicating not only the Committee<U+0092>s collective judgment but also the diversity of their views regarding the economic outlook and monetary policy. Many participants noted that developing a quantitative forecast that reflects the Committee<U+0092>s collective judgment could be challenging, given the range of their views about the economy<U+0092>s structure and dynamics. Several participants judged that the incremental gains in transparency that would result from developing and presenting such a consensus projection would be modest, given the breadth of information already provided in the Committee<U+0092>s policy statements, the minutes of Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meetings, and the Chairman<U+0092>s press briefings. Participants agreed to continue to explore ways to increase clarity and transparency in the Committee<U+0092>s policy communications; many noted that the Committee had introduced a number of changes in its communications over the past year or so, and emphasized that further changes should be considered carefully. At the end of the discussion, the Chairman asked the subcommittee on communications to explore the feasibility and workability of potential approaches to developing an FOMC consensus forecast. Developments in Financial Markets and the Federal Reserve<U+0092>s Balance Sheet The Manager of the System Open Market Account (SOMA) reported on developments in domestic and foreign financial markets during the period since the FOMC met on April 24<U+0096>25, 2012. He also reported on System open market operations, including the ongoing reinvestment into agency-guaranteed mortgage-backed securities (MBS) of principal payments received on SOMA holdings of agency debt and agency-guaranteed MBS as well as the operations related to the maturity extension program authorized at the September 20<U+0096>21, 2011, FOMC meeting. By unanimous vote, the Committee ratified the Desk<U+0092>s domestic transactions over _____________________________________________________________________________________________ Page 2 Federal Open Market Committee the intermeeting period. There were no intervention operations in foreign currencies for the System<U+0092>s account over the intermeeting period. By unanimous vote, the Authorization for Domestic Open Market Operations was amended to include the authority to conduct small-value operations for the purposes of routine testing of operational readiness. In addition, the Authorization was amended to include the authority to conduct intraday repurchase agreement (repo) transactions with foreign and international accounts to prevent daylight overdrafts in those accounts.4 Staff Review of the Economic Situation The information reviewed at the June 19<U+0096>20 meeting suggested that economic activity was expanding at a somewhat more modest pace than earlier in the year. Improvements in labor market conditions slowed in recent months, and the unemployment rate remained elevated. Consumer price inflation declined, primarily reflecting reductions in the prices of crude oil and gasoline, and measures of long-run inflation expectations continued to be stable. Private nonfarm employment rose at a slower pace in April and May than in the first quarter of the year, while total government employment continued to trend down. The unemployment rate stood at 8.2 percent in May, essentially the same as its average in the first quarter. The rate of long-duration unemployment remained very high, and the share of workers employed part time for economic reasons was little changed in recent months. Indicators of job openings and firms<U+0092> hiring plans were mixed, while initial claims for unemployment insurance were essentially unchanged over the intermeeting period at a level consistent with modest net job gains in the coming months. Manufacturing production edged up, on net, in April and May after rising at a robust pace in the first quarter. Meanwhile, the rate of manufacturing capacity utilization remained about the same as earlier in the year. In recent months, the output of motor vehicles and parts increased further, on balance, although at a slower rate than in the first quarter, while factory output outside of the motor vehicle sector only inched up.
