In Latin America, Consensus Forecast corrected its growth projections for the current year from -0.5% year-on-year in August to -0.3% year-to-year in September. Despite this small improvement in projections, at least four major economies in the region would remain in recession: Venezuela (-10.1%); Brazil (-3.2%); Ecuador (-2.3%); and Argentina (-1.5%). An important recovery of Latin America is expected in 2017 with a growth of around 2.2%, leaving only the Venezuelan economy in recession (-2.6%). The large countries of the region would benefit from a moderate increase in commodity prices next year, while the smaller economies, such as those of Central America and the Caribbean, would face more favorable conditions for their exports, given the greater dynamism of United States, its main commercial partner.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity and domestic demand are evolving positively. In January-August, the Monthly Indicator of Economic Activity (IMAE) shows real growth around 6.8% year-on-year, which indicates that the economy would be growing this year above its potential. Credit to the private sector in national currency shows a year-on-year growth rate of around 12.6% in September and continues to grow above the nominal product expansion. In the fiscal sector, public spending has slowed down in the second half of the year and it is expected, according to the most recent budget update, that at the end of 2016 the deficit will approach 2.7% of GDP and for 2017 it stood at 2.3% of GDP. On the side of external sector accounts, the current account deficit would end 2016 with a deficit of around 1.7% of GDP. Under this scenario, conditions are favorable for accumulating international reserves and maintaining the relative stability of the foreign exchange market.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to continue conducting monetary policy aimed at achieving its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to take the necessary measures against risks to stability of prices and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting for September 2017, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to maintain its monetary policy interest rate at 5.25% per annum.

The decision on the reference rate was taken after a comprehensive review of the balance of risks around the inflation projections, including the evolution of the main national macroeconomic indicators, the international environment relevant to the Dominican economy and the expectations of the domestic market . The monthly rate of inflation in the month of August amounted to 0.57%, so the accumulated rate to the eighth month of the year stood at 1.77%. Likewise, year-on-year inflation climbed to 3.18%, placing it within the target range of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0% of the Monetary Program. Additionally, core inflation, which reflects the monetary conditions of the economy, amounted to 2.27% year-on-year. The projections indicate that inflation would remain within the target range at the end of the year.

In the external context, the advanced economies experience an acceleration in their growth for the sixth consecutive quarter. The outlook is favorable for the United States of America (USA), the Euro Zone (ZE) and Japan. According to the Consensus Forecast, the US would grow 2.2% in 2017, after the annualized interquarterly growth of April-June, which reached 3.1%, was revised upwards. By 2018, the US is projected to grow 2.4%, in a context of normalization of monetary policy. As for the EZ, it is projected that the product would expand by 2.1% in 2017 and 1.8% in 2018. The dynamism of the advanced economies would have a positive impact on world economic activity, which would grow 3.0% in 2017 and 3.1% in 2018. It should be noted that the inflationary pressures of the developed economies remain relatively low, projecting 2.0% for the US in 2017 and 1.9% in 2018, as well as inflation rates of 1.5% in 2017 and 1.3% in 2018 for the ZE.

On the other hand, in Latin America (AL) there continues to be a gradual economic recovery, with the exception of Venezuela. In the case of Brazil, the largest economy in the region, it would grow 0.7% in 2017 and 2.3% in 2018. On the other hand, Mexico would expand 2.2% in both years, while Chile would grow 1.4% in 2017 and 2.9% in 2018 The projections for Latin America have been revised upwards and reflect that the economy of the region would expand 1.7% in 2017 and 2.6% in 2018, driven by more favorable terms of trade.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity reacted favorably after the expansionary measures taken at the end of July, such as the reduction of the monetary policy rate by 50 basis points and the reduction in the legal reserve by 2.2 percentage points. It should be noted that credit to the private sector in national currency has increased by RD $ 16,000 million since these measures were taken, so that positive prospects remain for the revitalization of domestic demand for the rest of 2017. In that sense, Growth is expected to approach its potential by the end of the year, even in a context of recovery from the damage caused by recent climate events. It is important to note that the World Bank approved a loan of US $ 150 million for the Dominican Republic with the purpose of facing natural disasters, which would facilitate the reactivation of economic activity during the last quarter of the year.

In the fiscal sector, a boost to public spending was recently announced, implying a more active fiscal policy for the rest of the year. Notwithstanding this decision, the Government announced that it would meet the deficit target of 2.3% of GDP, established in the National Budget for 2017. On the other hand, the external sector maintains its dynamism, contributing to the increase of foreign exchange earnings and creating a favorable environment for the relative stability of the foreign exchange market and for the accumulation of international reserves.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target and maintain macroeconomic stability. In that sense, it will continue to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to adopt the necessary measures against possible risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting in September 2018, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.50% per annum.

The decision to leave the reference rate unchanged was based on a detailed analysis of the balance of risks around inflation projections, including the main national macroeconomic indicators, market expectations, the relevant international environment and medium-term forecasts. . In recent months, inflationary pressures have moderated. In that sense, the cumulative inflation to the month of August stood at 1.44%, which is why inter-annual inflation fell from 4.43% in the month of July to 3.87% in August, below the central value of the goal of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0% established in the Monetary Program. Core inflation, linked to monetary conditions, fell to 2.59% year-on-year in August. In addition, the forecast system indicates that inflation would remain within the target range in the two-year monetary policy horizon.

In the external context, the growth prospects of the world economy continue at around 3.3% during 2018 and 3.1% in 2019. According to Consensus Forecast, the United States of America (USA) would grow 2.9% in 2018 and 2.6% in 2019. Given the dynamics of expansion and full employment of that economy, the monetary policy in the US continues with the process of normalization, gradually withdrawing the monetary stimulus in force since the global financial crisis. Under these conditions, market interest rates tend to rise and the US dollar appreciates.

On the other hand, the economy of the set of countries that make up the Euro Zone (ZE) would grow 2.1% in 2018 and 1.8% in 2019, while Japan would expand by 1.1% in 2018 and 1.2% in 2019, according to the Consensus Forecast. Given that inflationary pressures remain moderate in these countries, the monetary policy stance would remain expansive in the coming months.

The economic situation for emerging economies becomes less favorable as the perception of risk increases in countries such as Argentina, Turkey, South Africa and Brazil, among others, which is manifested in a reversal of capital flows in those economies with weak macroeconomic fundamentals. In contrast, the larger emerging economies such as India and China continue with significant dynamism. In that sense, India would expand 7.4% in 2018 and 7.8% in 2019, while China would grow by 6.6% and 6.4%, during those years.

The countries of Latin America (AL), with the exception of Venezuela, Argentina and Nicaragua, present a positive growth outlook this year, with an expansion of 1.9% in 2018 and 2.6% in 2019 in the region.

With regard to primary goods, uncertainty continues to be observed regarding international oil prices attributed to a combination of factors that include greater demand in the face of the momentum of the world economy, supply restrictions and geopolitical factors.

Domestically, the Dominican economy continues to evolve favorably, with strong macroeconomic fundamentals reflected in high growth and low inflation, as well as consolidation processes in fiscal and external accounts. After recent monetary measures, credit to the private sector in national currency has moderated its year-on-year expansion around 12.5% ??as of September. According to the Central Bank forecasting system, economic activity maintains its dynamism with year-on-year growth in 2018 in the range of 6.0% - 6.5%, while inflation would be around the lower limit of the target at the end of this year . For the next year, economic growth is projected to converge to its potential and inflation to approach the center of the target.

On the fiscal policy side, a moderation in public spending, together with tax revenues in line with the budget, has led to a deficit of the Non-Financial Public Sector of just 0.2% of GDP as of July. In the external sector, the momentum of foreign currency generating activities has substantially contributed to moderate the impact of higher oil prices on the Dominican economy and international reserves maintain levels equivalent to more than four months of imports, which favors stability relative of the exchange market.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve the inflation target and maintain macroeconomic stability. In this sense, the institution will continue monitoring the evolution of the world and national economy, in order to adopt the necessary measures against possible risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
BCRD maintains its monetary policy rate at 4.50% per year
At its monetary policy meeting in September 2019, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 4.50% per annum.

The benchmark decision is based on detailed risk balance analysis for inflation forecasts, including international and domestic macroeconomic indicators, market expectations and medium-term projections. August's monthly inflation was 0.47%, while cumulative inflation in the first eight months of the year stood at 1.99%. On the other hand, year-on-year inflation, i.e. from August 2018 to August 2019, stood at 1.72%, remaining below the lower bound of the target range. In addition, underlying inflation, reflecting monetary conditions, stood at 2.04% in August. Inflation expectations from economic analysts, as well as the BCRD's forecasting system, indicate that inflation would be at the end of 2019 around the lower bound of the target range of 4.0% to 1.0% and would remain close to the centre of the target range by 2020.

In the international environment, the uncertainty factors that have been gravitating this year persist, particularly those related to trade disputes between the United States of America and China, as well as geopolitical tensions in different parts of the world. In this context, the global economy is estimated to expand by 2.6% in 2019, while the 2020 growth projection is down to 2.5%, according to Consensus Forecasts.

The U.S. growth outlook stands at 2.3% for 2019 according to Consensus Forecasts, moderating to 1.8% by 2020. Taking into account the lower dynamism of economic activity and low inflationary pressures, the Federal Reserve decreased in September, for the second consecutive time, its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points, consistent with what is expected by market analysts. In addition, the Federal Reserve has been providing more liquidity to the financial system with the goal of reducing short-term interest rates.

As for the Eurozone, the growth outlook remains low, rising at 1.1% for both 2019 and 2020, affected by uncertainty surrounding the UK's exit process from the European Union (Brexit) and global trade disputes. Considering this adverse outlook and low inflation levels, the European Central Bank announced a package of expansive measures, highlighting the reduction in the interest rate of the permanent deposit facility (overnight), placing it at -0.50% per annum. It also announced a new round of purchases of sovereign debt assets in a monthly amount of $20 billion, as well as a liquidity provision program for the private sector credit pipeline through financial institutions.

On the other hand, Latin America's growth projections have deteriorated, projecting a regional expansion of 0.5% by 2019 according to Consensus Forecasts. The region's performance would be influenced by recessionary conditions in Venezuela, Argentina and Nicaragua, while the two largest economies, Brazil and Mexico, would grow below 1.0%. This combination of lower growth and volatility in international markets has contributed to the sharps of the depreciations of almost all currencies in emerging economies, and in particular Latin America, in recent months.

In terms of raw materials, the average Price of Texas Intermediate Oil (WTI) remained around US$55 per barrel during the month of September, despite having higher volatility associated with geopolitical tensions in oil-producing countries. The average price is expected to remain for the remainder of 2019 below $60 a barrel, a level set out in the National Budget, as a result of weakening global demand. On the other hand, the average price of gold remained above $1,500 per troy ounce in September, as it was used as a haven of value in an environment of high uncertainty.

In the domestic context, preliminary information from the Monthly Economic Activity Index (IMAE) indicates that aggregate demand has begun to recover in response to the recent implementation of expansive monetary measures. Indeed, after cumulative growth of 4.7% during the first half of the year, the economy expanded by 4.6% year-on-year in July and accelerated to 4.8% year-on-year in August. If this positive trend continues over the coming months, economic growth is expected to hover around its 5.0% potential by the end of the year.

In particular, monetary easing measures implemented since June, through the reduction by 100 basis points of the monetary policy rate and the release of more than RD$34 billion of legal lace resources to the productive sectors, have boosted private credit, which expands year-on-year by around 11%. Monetary conditions will remain favourable over the coming months as monetary policy transmission mechanisms operate, boosting domestic demand through increased investment and private consumption.

On the other hand, the process of consolidation of public finances is maintained, with a primary surplus expected to be achieved at the end of 2019, as stipulated in the National Budget. In the external sector, foreign exchange-generating activities such as foreign direct investment and remittances continue to perform well, compensating for recent tourism moderation, induced by lower global demand and the negative media campaign in the face of isolated cases in the sector. In this complex international environment, the Dominican Republic has maintained the relative stability of the exchange rate, presenting during this year a cumulative depreciation below the average of Latin American countries and emerging economies, as a result of the strength of macroeconomic fundamentals and credibility in its economic policies.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to drive monetary policy towards achieving its inflation target and the smooth functioning of financial and payment systems, thus contributing to the maintenance of macroeconomic stability. In this sense, the institution will continue to monitor the moderation of the world economy and factors of uncertainty both externally and internally and its impact on aggregate demand, being prepared to continue to react in a timely manner to factors that may generate deviations from the inflation target and affect Dominican economic growth.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic, at its Monetary Policy Meeting in October 2012, decided to keep its Monetary Policy Interest Rate unchanged at 5.00% per annum. In addition, he decided to leave his Lombard Rate unchanged at 7.00% per annum.

The decision regarding the benchmark interest rate is based on the fact that the most recent projections keep the inflation rate below the lower limit of the 2012 target and within the target of 5% <U+00B1> 1% for 2013 In the month of September, the interannual inflation rate rose to 2.60%, while the core interannual inflation was 3.53%. The forecast models suggest that in the monetary policy horizon, inflation would remain within the range established in the Monetary Program, while market expectations remain anchored around the target in the medium term.

In the external context, the latest projections of the IMF World Economic Outlook confirm the slow recovery of advanced countries while revealing the process of slowdown experienced by emerging economies. Financial tensions in the countries of the Eurozone have moderated, but the recession persists while uncertainty remains about its final correction. The announcement of a third round of quantitative easing in the United States would help to improve the economic conditions of that country in the short term while the dollar would tend to depreciate.

In the domestic sphere, domestic demand and production continue to evolve in positive terrain, although below its potential. During the period January-September, economic activity expanded 3.9% in real terms. In the financial market, interest rates continue to decline, as the transmission mechanism of monetary policy operates and a moderate recovery in private credit begins to be observed.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation in order to react timely to risks on price stability and good functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting in October 2013, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic decided to keep the Monetary Policy Rate (MPR) unchanged at 6.25% per annum.

The decision on the reference rate takes into account inflation projections and market expectations. The interannual inflation rate, corresponding to the period September 2012-September 2013, stood at 5.13%, while cumulative inflation to the ninth month of 2013 amounted to 3.57%. In monthly terms, September inflation was 0.49%, while core inflation, the indicator of price performance that best reflects the monetary policy stance, recorded a year-on-year rate of 4.83%.

In the external context, the growth outlook for the world economy, according to the IMF, has moderated during the current year (2.9%). For 2014, a better performance is expected (3.6%), as a result of a significant improvement in the advanced economies. The forecast of growth of the IMF for the United States of America (EUA) is 1.6% for 2013 and 2.6% for 2014. On the other hand, it is expected that the economy of the Eurozone will contract this year by 0.4%, recovering in 2014 with an expansion of around 1%. In Latin America, projections point to regional growth of 2.7% in 2013 and 3.1% in 2014.

Recently, the Federal Reserve Bank (FED) decided to maintain its TPM between 0% and 0.25% and continue with its program of purchase of financial assets for US $ 85 billion per month. This decision reduced the long-term international interest rates, helped to soften the trend towards the appreciation of the dollar and improved the expectations of the emerging economies that had been affected by the outflow of capital due to the uncertainty of a possible reversal of monetary policy. of the FED. The temporary fiscal agreement, after the closure of the US government, also helped to reduce pressures on international financial conditions that were quite restrictive. The international prices of raw materials are reduced below their value for the last two quarters.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity and domestic demand show an important improvement over the performance shown at the beginning of the year. The Gross Domestic Product grew by 5.5% in the third quarter, for an accumulated 2.9% in January-September, which indicates that by the end of the year it would be meeting the 3.0% projection of the Monetary Program. Product growth during the first nine months of the year is consistent with an expansion of credit to the private sector in national currency of around 15% per annum in the month of September. It is expected that in the last quarter of the year, the relative stability of the exchange rate will be maintained, given the entry of important flows from sovereign bonds, pending disbursements from multilateral organizations, tourists and absent Dominicans who visit us at Christmas and the contributions of Barrick Gold.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation in order to take the necessary measures against risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.

At its monetary policy meeting for the month of October 2014, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic decided to keep the monetary policy interest rate unchanged at 6.25% per annum, in line with the neutral position it has maintained in recent months.

The decision on the benchmark interest rate took into account the balance of risks around the inflation projections, as well as the performance of the rest of the main macroeconomic indicators, market expectations and the relevant international environment for the Dominican economy. Last September, cumulative inflation in the nine months computed stood at 2.53%, while the interannual rate of inflation fell to 2.83%, below the lower end of the target range of 4.5% <U+00B1> 1% for 2014 In the same way, the interannual core inflation, which is related to monetary conditions, fell from 3.26% in August to 3.07% in September. It is important to note that inflation in recent months has been influenced by low inflationary pressures of external origin, and it is expected that it will be within the target range in the policy horizon.

In the external context, the most recent data maintain the positive economic outlook for the United States of America. The Federal Reserve concluded its policy of monetary stimulus by buying financial assets, indicating that it would keep the monetary policy interest rate unchanged for extended time, between 0% and 0.25% until mid-2015, while consolidating the recovery of that economy and continues to improve labor market conditions.

In the case of the Eurozone, economic activity remains moderate, projecting an expansion in 2014 and 2015 of 0.8% and 1.2%, respectively, with the risk of a deflation scenario. For Latin America, a lower economic dynamism is projected, with a GDP growth of 1.2% expected in 2014 to reach 2.2% in 2015 due to signs of recession in countries such as Brazil, Argentina and Venezuela, and moderate performance in other important economies of the region. .

In the domestic sphere, economic activity maintained a positive growth trend, expanding by 7.0% during the January-September period, with a growth rate of over 6.0% for the whole year of 2014. As a reflection of this dynamism, credit to The private sector in domestic currency is expanding at an interannual rate of more than 15.0% and would converge at rates close to 12.0% at the end of the year, in line with nominal GDP growth. On the fiscal policy side, budget execution points to a smaller deficit than expected in 2014 (2.8%), because revenues grow at an annual rate higher than that of public spending.

Tourism and remittances reflect a better than expected performance, which, together with the drop registered in the prices of oil and other raw materials, would contribute to the improvement in external accounts, projecting that the current account deficit closed at 3.9% of the GDP in 2014. The IMF forecasts that the trend in the price of oil will continue to moderate for 2015, with which it is estimated that there would be a reduction of some US $ 600 million in the Dominican oil bill. Due to this effect, a significant reduction in the current account deficit is projected at levels between 2.9% and 3.1% of GDP by the end of 2015, a situation that will favor the relative stability of the exchange rate as important foreign currency savings take place. At the same time, it would allow the Central Bank to continue strengthening its levels of international reserves.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to implement monetary policy aimed at achieving its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to take the necessary measures against risks to the stability of the economy. prices and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting in October 2015, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.00% per annum.

The decision on the reference rate was adopted after a complete analysis of the balance of risks around inflation projections, market expectations, the national macroeconomic outlook and the relevant international environment for the Dominican economy. It was observed that in September the year-on-year inflation rate stood at 0.39% and that, in cumulative terms, inflation reached 1.33% at the end of that month. On the other hand, core inflation, an indicator that reflects the monetary conditions of the economy, was 1.90% year-on-year in September. Forecasts indicate that inflation would approach the lower limit of the target established in the Monetary Program for the end of 2015, gradually converging towards the center of the range of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0% in 2016.

In the external context, according to the Consensus Forecast, world production would grow 2.6% in 2015, accelerating to 3.0% in 2016, driven by the performance of developed economies, which have benefited from important monetary stimuli. According to forecasts made during the month of October by Consensus, the economy of the United States of America (USA) would grow 2.5% in 2015 and 2.7% in 2016, while the Euro Zone (ZE) would expand by 1.4% and 1.7% during those years, respectively. Inflation in the industrialized economies of Europe and the US would remain low, close to zero, during the current year. For 2016, the US Consumer Price Index would increase to 1.9%, close to its medium-term goal, while inflation in the ZE would be 1.2%. It should be noted that the labor market, both in the US and the ZE, shows reductions in unemployment. In the United States, the unemployment rate stood at 5.1% in September, a level considered to be full employment by the Federal Reserve. In the Euro Zone, the unemployment rate fell from 11.0% to 10.8% in the month of September.

In another order, the main economies of emerging markets continue to slow their growth and some of them, as is the case in Brazil, remain in recession. China registered a growth of 6.9% during the third quarter, well below the average of the last decade. According to the International Monetary Fund, China's economy would grow 6.8% this year and 6.3% next year. Taking into account this behavior of China and other large emerging economies, as well as the risks arising from the global economy, the US Federal Reserve left its benchmark rate unchanged at its most recent monetary policy meeting.

In the case of Latin America, a contraction of 0.7% is projected in 2015, recovering gradually in 2016 with a moderate growth of 0.5%. This year's Latin American performance is highly influenced by the estimated contraction of the economies of Brazil (-2.8%) and Venezuela (-7.8%), as well as by the projected low growth for Argentina (0.9%) and the slowdown in the growth of other important exporters of commodities, such as Chile (2.1%) and Peru (2.7%).

In international markets, the tendency to the appreciation of the dollar is maintained, while oil prices continue below the average of recent years. This behavior has contributed to low inflation in the United States and Europe, in contrast to what happened in the large countries of Latin America, exporters of raw materials, where exchange rate depreciation has generated higher inflation.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity in the Dominican Republic continues to show high dynamism in the short term. In that sense, the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) presents a real growth rate of 6.7% in interannual terms in January-September. The growth was even greater in the July-September period, at 7.1%, according to preliminary figures. Consistent with this dynamic of growth, loans to the private sector in local currency grew at an annual rate of around 11.2% as of October, in line with the expansion of nominal GDP.

In the context of fiscal policy, budget execution points to the government continuing its process of fiscal consolidation, reaching a primary surplus in the current year. According to the Budget approved for 2016, consolidation would continue during that year with a primary surplus of around 0.7% of GDP. and a deficit for the year equivalent to 2.3% of GDP. With regard to the external sector, the macroeconomic fundamentals are consolidated with a current account balance that would close the year with its lowest deficit in the last decade, due to lower oil prices and the better performance of income from tourism, remittances and exports of free zones. These positive results in the fiscal and external accounts, would facilitate the accumulation of reserves and the relative stability of the exchange market.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to implement monetary policy aimed at achieving its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to take the necessary measures against risks to the stability of the economy. prices and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.

At its monetary policy meeting in October 2016, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic decided to increase its monetary policy rate (MPR) by 50 basis points, from 5.00% per annum to 5.50% per annum, effective November 1. According to the BCRD's short-term liquidity management scheme, the rate of paid deposits (overnight) is increased from 3.50% to 4.00% per annum and the rate of expansion facilities (repos) increases from 6.50% to 7.00% annual.

The decision regarding the reference rate has a preventive character and seeks to generate certainty for economic agents. This measure takes into account the balance of risks around inflation projections, market expectations, the domestic macroeconomic context, as well as the relevant international environment for the Dominican economy; in particular the upward expectations of Federal Reserve interest rates (FED), the recent trend of higher international oil prices and the uncertainty that the electoral process of the United States of America (USA) has generated in international markets, among others. In September, the interannual inflation rate stood at 1.35%, while cumulative inflation reached 0.35% at the end of that month. Likewise, the interannual core inflation, related to monetary conditions, amounted to 1.78 percent.

Although inflation has remained persistently below the target range and the economy has grown at rates above its potential, this behavior is due to the positive supply shock, mainly associated with the fall in international oil prices. However, during the last months there has been a gradual increase in oil prices, while projections indicate that this process would continue in the policy horizon. In that sense, the inflation projections for 2017 indicate a moderate upward trend, which could imply potential risks of deviations from the inflation target of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0%. In the same way, higher oil prices would have an impact on the projected result of the Current Account. Likewise, according to data from the Macroeconomic Expectations Survey, we observe an upward behavior of market inflation expectations by economic agents.

In the external environment, the United States of America recorded a growth rate of 1.5% year-on-year in the third quarter of the year, exceeding market expectations for that period. This result strengthens the probability that the Federal Reserve will resume the normalization of its monetary policy rate in the coming months. According to the most recent information from the Consensus Forecast, the US would grow 1.5% in 2016 and 2.2% in 2017. It should be noted that in the international financial markets there has been some uncertainty regarding the US electoral process and its possible impact on external liquidity conditions. . Given the electoral uncertainty in the US, some emerging economies, such as Mexico, have presented volatility in their exchange markets.

On the other hand, the Euro Zone (ZE) would expand at interannual rates of around 1.6% in the current year, supported by the performance of Germany (1.8%) and Spain (3.1%). For 2017, this region would experience a moderate slowdown, growing 1.3% year-on-year, probably influenced by the impact of Brexit.

In Latin America, Consensus Forecast expects a contraction of economic activity of -0.3% this year, slightly better than the previous projections of -0.5% for the region. The low projected growth for Latin America this year is explained by significant recessions in countries such as: Venezuela (-10.3%); Brazil (-3.2%); Ecuador (-2.0%); and Argentina (-1.6%). It is important to point out that contrary to what happens with these commodity exporting economies, the economies of Central America, oil importers, have kept growing with low levels of inflation in 2016. By 2017, Latin America would grow around 2.1%, being Venezuela (-3.5%) the only economy that would remain in recession.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity continues to expand at a rate above its potential. In January-September, the real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) grew 6.9% year-on-year and current forecasts indicate that economic growth at the end of the year would be 6.5%, the highest in Latin America for the third consecutive year. To the extent that the positive supply shock dissipates, that is to say that oil prices present an upward trajectory, real GDP would converge to its potential level in the policy horizon. In the financial sector, credit to the private sector in national currency expanded at a rate of around 12.0% year-on-year in October, growing above nominal GDP and beyond that contemplated in the Monetary Program.

In the fiscal sector, public spending has decelerated noticeably in the second half of the year and it is expected that by the end of 2016 the deficit will approach what was stipulated in the latest projection of the National Budget, consolidating around 2.3% of GDP for Next year. On the side of external sector accounts, the current account deficit would end 2016 with a deficit close to 1.7% of GDP. This context of solid macroeconomic fundamentals, together with the Central Bank's preventive decision to increase its Monetary Policy Rate, contributes to maintain propitious conditions to accumulate international reserves and promote the relative stability of the exchange market.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to continue conducting monetary policy aimed at achieving its inflation target and maintaining macroeconomic stability, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to adopt the necessary measures in the face of risks regarding price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting in October 2017, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.25% per annum.

The decision on the reference rate was made after reviewing the balance of risks around the inflation forecasts, the evolution of the main national macroeconomic indicators, the international environment relevant to the Dominican economy, market expectations and the projections of that set of variables. Monthly inflation was 0.64% in September, while the accumulated rate at the ninth month of the year stood at 2.42%. Likewise, year-on-year inflation reached 3.80%, close to the center of the Monetary Program's target range. Additionally, core inflation, related to monetary conditions, was 2.29% year-on-year. The projections indicate that, at the end of this year, inflation would be around the lower limit of the goal of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0%.

In the external context, the growth of the world economy has presented a performance better than expected in the second half of the year, attributed to the expansion of production in advanced economies, while inflationary pressures remain contained. According to Consensus Forecast, the United States of America (USA) would grow 2.2% in 2017 and 2.4% in 2018, while the product of the Euro Zone (ZE) would expand by 2.2% and 1.8%, during those years. The inflationary pressures of the developed economies remain relatively low, projecting 2.0% for the US in 2017 and 2018, as well as inflation rates of 1.5% in 2017 and 1.3% in 2018 for the ZE.

In Latin America there is a gradual economic recovery, with the exception of Venezuela. Consensus Forecast projections indicate that the region's economy would grow 1.7% in 2017 and 2.6% in 2018, driven by more favorable terms of trade. The dynamism of the advanced economies together with the better expected performance in the emerging economies would have a positive impact on the global economic activity that, according to the International Monetary Fund, would grow 3.1% in 2017 and 2018.

International prices of primary goods have increased in recent months. The price of a barrel of West Texas oil (WTI) reached US $ 54 at the end of October. However, it is expected that by the end of the year it will be around US $ 52.0 a barrel, below the price observed at the end of 2016. International financial conditions remain favorable for emerging economies in the short term due to the abundant liquidity Worldwide.

Domestically, economic activity maintains positive prospects registering a growth of 4.0% in the period January-August 2017. The decrease in monetary policy rates, together with the measure to reduce the legal reserve of 2.2 percentage points, have had a multiplying effect on loans to the private sector in national currency, which have increased by almost RD $ 24 billion pesos, in less than three months.

Recently, the Monetary Board eliminated the sectorization in the use of legal reserve, so that the RD $ 11,515 million pending placement of the resources of the legal reserve, could be lent to any sector that demands it. This measure, together with the entry into force of some aspects of the Asset Evaluation Regulation (REA), particularly for the benefit of sectors such as agriculture and Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MIPYMES), will have a favorable impact on credit, employment and the growth of the economy. At the end of October, private credit in national currency grew around 10% year-on-year.

With regard to fiscal policy, the Government maintains its commitment to the deficit target established in the National Budget, while strengthening the coordination of monetary and fiscal policies. On the other hand, the external sector shows a positive behavior, contributing to the increase in foreign exchange earnings and creating a favorable environment for the relative stability of the foreign exchange market and for the accumulation of international reserves.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target and maintain macroeconomic stability. In that sense, it will continue to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to adopt the necessary measures against possible risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting in October 2018, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.50% per annum.

The decision to leave the reference rate unchanged is based on a detailed analysis of the balance of risks around inflation forecasts, including quantitative and qualitative information from the relevant international environment, national macroeconomic indicators, market expectations and projections. medium term of that set of variables.

Cumulative inflation as of September stood at 1.52%, while year-on-year inflation, from September 2017 to September 2018, fell for the third consecutive month, going from 3.87% in August to 3.29% in September, staying within the goal of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0% established in the Monetary Program.

Core inflation, linked to monetary conditions, fell to 2.53% year-on-year in September. The forecast system indicates that, on average, inflation would remain within the target range in the two-year monetary policy horizon. In the external context, the relevant economic outlook for the Dominican economy is influenced by the normalization of monetary policy in the United States of America (USA), the appreciation of the dollar in international markets and the gradual increase in oil prices. Other factors such as the increase in volatility in international capital markets, global trade tensions and the increase in uncertainty in some emerging economies also contribute to what is perceived as a changing international scenario.

In this context, according to Consensus Forecast, the world economy would grow 3.2% in 2018 and 3.1% in 2019, driven by the continued dynamism of the US economy that would expand 2.9% and 2.6%, respectively, during those years. Given the growth of the US in the context of full employment and inflation above the programmed target, it is expected that the process of increases in the benchmark interest rate of the Federal Reserve Bank will continue. It should be noted that the normalization process of monetary policy has been accompanied by an expansive fiscal policy that has increased the public deficit in that country, which is estimated to be around 4.0% of GDP by 2018. On the other hand, the economy of the community of countries that make up the Euro Zone (ZE) would grow 2.0% in 2018 and 1.8% in 2019. Given that inflationary pressures remain moderate in these countries, the monetary policy stance of the European Central Bank would remain expansive in the medium term, which would help to increase the interest rate differential with the US, promoting a greater appreciation of the dollar.

The economic situation for emerging markets shows a greater degree of uncertainty, with a slowdown observed in some economies with weak macroeconomic fundamentals. However, there are emerging economies that show significant dynamism, such as the cases of India and China whose economies would expand during 2018 by 7.3% and 6.6%, respectively. In the case of Latin America, the growth projections of countries such as Venezuela, Brazil, Argentina and Nicaragua have been corrected downwards. On the other hand, the growth prospects of other economies in the region with solid foundations such as Chile, Peru, Colombia and the Dominican Republic have been revised upwards. Domestically, economic activity continues to grow above its potential. In effect, the real Gross Domestic Product expanded by 6.9% during the first nine months of 2018, driven by a year-on-year growth of 7.3% in the third quarter. According to the Central Bank's forecasting system, economic activity would continue to grow above its potential in the current year, closing 2018 with growth of around 6.5%. Consistent with this trend, credit to the private sector in national currency continues to expand close to 12% year-on-year to the month of October, while monetary aggregates present growth rates consistent with the estimated expansion of nominal GDP.

On the fiscal policy side, the evolution of public finances over the course of the year suggests that the Central Government would close in December near the deficit target set in the 2018 Budget. As of September, the growth rate of the income is of two digits, at the same time as the public expenditure expands moderately. In the external sector, the foreign exchange generating activities maintain a remarkable dynamism, foreseeing that the Current Account deficit is located slightly above -1.0% of GDP at the end of the year, associated with higher oil prices. The good performance of the external sector has facilitated the accumulation of international reserves, which remain at levels above US $ 7,000 million, which contributes to the relative stability of the foreign exchange market.

The consolidation process of public finances and the low current account deficits, in a context of high economic growth and controlled inflation, are a reflection of our strong macroeconomic fundamentals. In effect, the country risk perception indicator for the Dominican Republic calculated by the JP Morgan firm (EMBI) is at the end of October about 100 basis points below the risk indicator for Latin America, being This is the level of risk relative to the lowest region in history, which reflects the confidence of investors in the Dominican economy based on the strength of its fundamentals. The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve the inflation target and to maintain macroeconomic stability, as well as to ensure the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems. In this sense, the monetary institution remains attentive to the evolution of the monetary policy normalization of the United States and its impact on the interest rate differential with the Dominican Republic, as well as the price of oil and the dynamics of the dollar in the international market, and is ready to react in a timely manner to any factor that jeopardizes compliance with its inflation target.
BCRD maintains its monetary policy rate at 4.50% per year
At its monetary policy meeting in October 2019, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 4.50% per annum.

The benchmark decision is based on detailed risk balance analysis for inflation forecasts, including international and domestic macroeconomic indicators, market expectations and medium-term projections. September's monthly inflation was 0.38%, while cumulative inflation in the first nine months of the year stood at 2.38%. On the other hand, year-on-year inflation, i.e. from September 2018 to September 2019, stood at 2.02%, remaining below the lower bound of the target range. Underlying inflation, reflecting monetary conditions, stood at 2.14% in September. Inflation expectations from economic analysts and the BCRD forecasting system indicate that inflation would be closer to the heart of the target range of 4.0% x 1.0% at the end of 2019 and would remain around the core value of the target during 2020.

In the international environment, the pockets of uncertainty that have been gravitating this year persist, particularly those related to trade disputes between the United States of America (USA) and China, as well as socio-political tensions in different parts of the world. Against this convulsing outlook, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) corrected its growth projections downwards, estimating an expansion of the global economy of 3.0% in 2019, the lowest in a decade, and a slight recovery to 3.4% in 2020.

The U.S. growth outlook has moderated, rising at 2.4% for 2019 and 2.1% by 2020 according to the IMF, influenced by a slowdown in private investment, the dissipation of the effects of fiscal stimulus, and the impact of trade war. Taking into account the lower dynamism of economic activity and low inflationary pressures, the Federal Reserve decreased its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points in October, for the third consecutive time. In addition, the Federal Reserve has been providing greater liquidity to the financial system through repurchase agreements (REPOS) and Treasury bill purchases on the secondary market, with the goal of lowering short-term interest rates and normalizing the yield curve, which had been reversed in recent months reflecting short-term interest rates higher than long-term interest rates. Based on the content of the Fed's latest press release, market analysts anticipate a pause in the process of lowering federal fund interest rates in the coming months.
BCRD maintains its monetary policy rate at 4.50% per year
At its monetary policy meeting in October 2019, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 4.50% per annum.

The benchmark decision is based on detailed risk balance analysis for inflation forecasts, including international and domestic macroeconomic indicators, market expectations and medium-term projections. September's monthly inflation was 0.38%, while cumulative inflation in the first nine months of the year stood at 2.38%. On the other hand, year-on-year inflation, i.e. from September 2018 to September 2019, stood at 2.02%, remaining below the lower bound of the target range. Underlying inflation, reflecting monetary conditions, stood at 2.14% in September. Inflation expectations from economic analysts and the BCRD forecasting system indicate that inflation would be closer to the heart of the target range of 4.0% x 1.0% at the end of 2019 and would remain around the core value of the target during 2020.

In the international environment, the pockets of uncertainty that have been gravitating this year persist, particularly those related to trade disputes between the United States of America (USA) and China, as well as socio-political tensions in different parts of the world. Against this convulsing outlook, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) corrected its growth projections downwards, estimating an expansion of the global economy of 3.0% in 2019, the lowest in a decade, and a slight recovery to 3.4% in 2020.

The U.S. growth outlook has moderated, rising at 2.4% for 2019 and 2.1% by 2020 according to the IMF, influenced by a slowdown in private investment, the dissipation of the effects of fiscal stimulus, and the impact of trade war. Taking into account the lower dynamism of economic activity and low inflationary pressures, the Federal Reserve decreased its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points in October, for the third consecutive time. In addition, the Federal Reserve has been providing greater liquidity to the financial system through repurchase agreements (REPOS) and Treasury bill purchases on the secondary market, with the goal of lowering short-term interest rates and normalizing the yield curve, which had been reversed in recent months reflecting short-term interest rates higher than long-term interest rates. Based on the content of the Fed's latest press release, market analysts anticipate a pause in the process of lowering federal fund interest rates in the coming months.

In this sense, these monetary easing measures have been meeting the objective of stimulating domestic demand, with reductions in the benchmark interest rate that have even been higher than those implemented by the Federal Reserve, which was decisive in the Decision of the Open Market Operations Committee to keep the monetary policy rate unchanged. Expansive monetary conditions are helping the economy remain the region's leader in growth, in a context of price stability. Given the global low interest rate and high uncertainty environment, the strength of macroeconomic fundamentals exhibited by the Dominican Republic places the country as an attractive destination for international investors.

In the external sector, foreign exchange-generating activities such as foreign direct investment and remittances continue to perform well, compensating for recent tourism moderation. The flow of tourists is expected to recover to normal in the coming months, to which the recent announcement of the FBI investigation into adverse events in the sector a few months ago will contribute.

Importantly, the increased exchange rate volatility experienced in recent months is not associated with macroeconomic fundamentals, but rather to the complex international environment described and the uncertainty of the domestic electoral process that has caused some apprehension in some economic sectors. In this regard, the Central Bank maintains high levels of international reserves and has put the electronic forex platform into operation, which will contribute to greater transparency and efficiency in the foreign exchange market, as well as better training of the expectations of private actors. In addition, the balance of payments current account is expected to close the year with a deficit of about 1.6% of GDP, below its historical average and that high levels of capital flows will remain.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to drive monetary policy towards achieving its inflation target and the smooth functioning of financial and payment systems, thus contributing to the maintenance of macroeconomic stability. In this sense, the institution will continue to monitor the moderation of the world economy and factors of uncertainty both externally and internally and its impact on aggregate demand, being prepared to continue to react in a timely manner to factors that may generate deviations from the inflation target and affect Dominican economic growth.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic, in its Monetary Policy Meeting of November 2012, decided to keep its Monetary Policy Interest Rate unchanged at 5.00% per annum. At the same time, he decided to leave his Lombard Rate unchanged at 7.00% per annum.

In October, the year-on-year inflation rate rose to 2.82%, while core interannual inflation fell to 3.31%. It is expected that by the end of 2012 it will be below the lower limit of the goal. However, the decision to leave the benchmark interest rate unchanged is based on the fact that the most recent projections indicate that inflation in 2013 would be within the target of 5% <U+00B1> 1 percentage point and market expectations are consistent with these predictions. In the monetary policy horizon, the forecast models show that inflation would remain within the target.

In the external context, the situation of the Euro Zone has deteriorated, while the United States (USA) shows a higher growth rate in the third quarter of the year, higher than expected by the market. The risks related to the fiscal situation in the European Union and in the United States have increased, generating uncertainty at an international level. Some Latin American countries, such as Argentina and Brazil, show signs of weakening in their growth rate. The prices of primary goods tend to moderate, while the US dollar has experienced some appreciation.

In the domestic sphere, although production and domestic demand are evolving below their potential, credit to the private sector in national currency begins to recover, which should lead to a greater dynamism of economic activity and to gradually close the product gap , in an orderly public finance environment.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to react in a timely manner to eventual risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting in October 2013, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic decided to keep the Monetary Policy Rate (MPR) unchanged at 6.25% per annum.

The decision on the reference rate takes into account inflation projections and market expectations. The interannual inflation rate, corresponding to the period September 2012-September 2013, stood at 5.13%, while cumulative inflation to the ninth month of 2013 amounted to 3.57%. In monthly terms, September inflation was 0.49%, while core inflation, the indicator of price performance that best reflects the monetary policy stance, recorded a year-on-year rate of 4.83%.

In the external context, the growth outlook for the world economy, according to the IMF, has moderated during the current year (2.9%). For 2014, a better performance is expected (3.6%), as a result of a significant improvement in the advanced economies. The forecast of growth of the IMF for the United States of America (EUA) is 1.6% for 2013 and 2.6% for 2014. On the other hand, it is expected that the economy of the Eurozone will contract this year by 0.4%, recovering in 2014 with an expansion of around 1%. In Latin America, projections point to regional growth of 2.7% in 2013 and 3.1% in 2014.

Recently, the Federal Reserve Bank (FED) decided to maintain its TPM between 0% and 0.25% and continue with its program of purchase of financial assets for US $ 85 billion per month. This decision reduced the long-term international interest rates, helped to soften the trend towards the appreciation of the dollar and improved the expectations of the emerging economies that had been affected by the outflow of capital due to the uncertainty of a possible reversal of monetary policy. of the FED. The temporary fiscal agreement, after the closure of the US government, also helped to reduce pressures on international financial conditions that were quite restrictive. The international prices of raw materials are reduced below their value for the last two quarters.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity and domestic demand show an important improvement over the performance shown at the beginning of the year. The Gross Domestic Product grew by 5.5% in the third quarter, for an accumulated 2.9% in January-September, which indicates that by the end of the year it would be meeting the 3.0% projection of the Monetary Program. Product growth during the first nine months of the year is consistent with an expansion of credit to the private sector in national currency of around 15% per annum in the month of September. It is expected that in the last quarter of the year, the relative stability of the exchange rate will be maintained, given the entry of important flows from sovereign bonds, pending disbursements from multilateral organizations, tourists and absent Dominicans who visit us at Christmas and the contributions of Barrick Gold.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation in order to take the necessary measures against risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic, at its monetary policy meeting for the month of November 2014, decided to keep the monetary policy interest rate (MPR) unchanged at 6.25% per annum, in line with the neutral policy stance maintained since last rate review fifteen months ago.

The decision on the benchmark interest rate took into account the balance of risks around the inflation projections, as well as the performance of the main macroeconomic indicators, market expectations and the relevant international environment for the Dominican economy. Last October, accumulated inflation stood at 2.44%, while the year-on-year inflation rate rose to 2.88%, below the lower end of the target range of 4.5% <U+00B1> 1% for 2014. Likewise, inflation The interannual core, which is related to monetary conditions, was reduced to 3.11%. It should be noted that the recent evolution of inflation has been influenced by the fall in prices of external origin, particularly in oil. It is expected that inflation will be within the target range in the policy horizon.

In the external context, the most recent data confirm the favorable economic conditions of the United States of America (USA), our main trading partner. Indeed, the most recent information on US growth shows an expansion of 3.9% in the third quarter of the year, better than expected by the market. According to the Consensus Forecast, the EUA would grow 2.2% in the current year, expecting an even greater expansion by 2015, around 3.0%. Despite this dynamism, the market expects the Federal Reserve of the United States (FED) to maintain the monetary policy interest rate unchanged, between 0% and 0.25% until mid-2015. This policy position is consistent with the recovery of the labor market, which registered an unemployment rate of 5.8% in October, showing a trend towards what the FED considers its potential unemployment rate at around 5.25%.

On the other hand, economic activity in the Eurozone remains moderate, projecting an expansion of 0.8% in 2014 and 1.1% in 2015, according to Consensus Forecast. Latin America has been affected by the decline in commodity prices in international markets, slowing growth in some of the largest economies, particularly in Brazil, Venezuela and Argentina. Consensus Forecast projects an economic expansion in this region that is lower than in recent years, with GDP growth expected of 1.0% in 2014 and 1.8% in 2015.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity maintained a positive growth trend as it expanded 7.2% during the January-September period, with a growth rate of more than 6.5% expected for the whole of 2014. As a reflection of this dynamism, credit to The private sector in national currency is expanding satisfactorily and is expected to close the year with a growth rate close to 14.0% year-on-year. The macroeconomic accounts show a significant improvement, with projections of current account deficit of 3.9% of GDP for 2014 and in the range 2.9% -3.1% of GDP for 2015, a situation that will favor the relative stability of the exchange rate, at the same time that would allow the Central Bank to continue strengthening its levels of international reserves. Likewise, the fiscal deficit for this year would be around 2.8% of GDP, while the 2015 Budget contemplates a deficit of 2.4% of GDP, product of a primary surplus of 0.5% of GDP, which would help to improve the sustainability of the debt.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to implement monetary policy aimed at achieving its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to take the necessary measures against risks to the stability of the economy. prices and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting in November 2015, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.00% per annum.

The decision on the benchmark rate was preceded by a broad analysis of the macroeconomic outlook, including the risk balance around inflation projections, market expectations and the relevant international environment for the Dominican economy. It was observed that in the month of October, the interannual rate of inflation amounted to 1.23% and that, in cumulative terms, inflation reached 2.08% until that month. Additionally, core inflation, which reflects the monetary conditions of the economy, remained at 1.91% year-on-year. Inflation would end around the lower limit of the target established in the Monetary Program for 2015, gradually converging towards the center of the range of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0% in 2016.

In the external context, according to Consensus Forecast, the world economy would grow 2.6% in 2015, accelerating to 2.9% in 2016, driven by the performance of developed countries. The United States of America (USA) would experience an expansion rate of around 2.4% in 2015 and 2.6% in 2016, while the Euro Zone (ZE) would expand by 1.5% and 1.7% during those years, respectively. Inflation in the industrialized economies of Europe and the US would remain close to zero during 2015. By 2016, it would increase by around 1.7% in the US and 1.1% in the EZ, in an environment of lower unemployment.

On the other hand, the outlook for the main emerging economies continues to fall, with the recession in Brazil and the slowdown in the rest of the net exporter economies of primary goods in Latin America, projecting a contraction of -0.8% in 2015 and recovering gradually in 2016, with a moderate growth of 0.2%. The Latin American economic panorama in 2015 is influenced by the estimated contraction of the economies of Brazil (-3.0%) and Venezuela (-8.0%), as well as by the projected low growth for Argentina (1.0%) and the deceleration of the growth of others important exporters of commodities, such as Chile (2.1%) and Peru (2.8%).

For its part, China's economy would grow 6.8% this year and 6.3% next year, below the average of the last decade, according to projections from the International Monetary Fund. In the international exchange markets, the tendency to the appreciation of the US dollar continues, while the prices of primary goods, particularly oil and gold, continue below the average of recent years.

Domestically, economic activity evolves favorably in the short term. The recent IMF mission that evaluated national economic conditions reaffirmed that the Dominican Republic continues to be among the most dynamic economies in the region. In that sense, the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) projected for 2015 contemplates a real growth rate in the range 6.5% -7.0%. Consistent with the evolution of nominal GDP, loans to the private sector in national currency grew at an interannual rate of around 11.0% as of November.

Regarding the external sector, the current account balance would end the year with the lowest deficit in the last ten years, around 2.0% of GDP, due to lower oil prices and the good performance of revenues from tourism, remittances and exports of free zones. With regard to fiscal policy, the projection of the primary surplus in the current year is maintained, while for 2016, a primary surplus of around 0.7% of GDP is contemplated. These positive results in the external and fiscal accounts would facilitate the accumulation of reserves and the relative stability of the exchange market.

The Central Bank confirms its commitment to implement monetary policy aimed at achieving its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to take the necessary measures against possible risks to stability of prices and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its November 2016 monetary policy meeting, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to maintain its monetary policy rate (MPR) at 5.5% per year.

Although the conditions that led to a preventive increase of the MPR at the last meeting are maintained, such as the expected increase in the monetary policy interest rate of the Federal Reserve, the gradual increase in oil prices and the expectations generated around it. to the electoral process of the United States, the BCRD chose to keep its reference rate unchanged. This decision was taken while waiting for more information about the economic impact that could be generated by extreme climatic events that occurred recently.

The decision regarding the reference rate weighs the balance of risks on the inflation projections based on the analysis of the main internal macroeconomic indicators, market expectations and the relevant international environment for the Dominican economy. In October, the year-on-year inflation rate decreased to 0.91%, while cumulative inflation to the tenth month of 2016 was 0.65%. Likewise, the interannual core inflation, related to monetary conditions, remained at 1.78 percent.

In the external context, contrary to expectations, the markets' reaction has tended to increase the stock market indicators after the recent elections in the United States of America (USA). At the same time, the dollar has strengthened and long-term interest rates have increased due to a higher probability of a rate increase by the Federal Reserve Bank. In this context, Consensus Forecast estimates that the US economy would grow 1.5% in 2016 and 2.2% in 2017. On the other hand, the Euro Zone (ZE) would expand around 1.6% in 2016, supported by the performance of Germany ( 1.8%) and Spain (3.1%), mainly. For 2017, this region would experience a moderate slowdown, growing 1.3% year-on-year, influenced by the impact of Brexit and the uncertainty in France and Italy, countries that face short-term electoral processes.

In Latin America (AL), the indicators of most of the capital markets in the region have shown a downward trend in recent weeks. In the real sector, the LA economy is still in recession. According to Consensus Forecast, the region would contract by -0.4% in the current year due to important recessions in countries such as: Venezuela (-10.3%); Brazil (-3.3%); Ecuador (-2.0%); and Argentina (-2.0%). Contrary to the prospects of these export economies of primary goods, Central America and the Dominican Republic, countries that have benefited from the low prices of commodities, particularly oil, experience positive growth rates with low levels of inflation. For 2017, Latin America would grow around 2.1%, with Venezuela (-3.2%) the only economy that would remain in recession.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity and domestic demand evolve favorably in the short term, growing above its potential level. The economy is expected to grow in the range of 6.0% -6.5%, the highest growth in the region, even considering the possible negative effects of the recent floods on the results of the fourth quarter. Credit to the private sector in national currency continues to expand at a rate close to 12.0% in November and would close the year with an expansion greater than the estimated nominal product.

With regard to fiscal policy, the growth rate of public spending has slowed significantly in the second half of the year, which implies a more restrictive fiscal stance and in line with the projection of a deficit of 2.7% of GDP, presented in the latest revision of the Budget for the current year. It is expected that reconstruction efforts in areas of the country affected by the recent floods will have a moderate impact on the fiscal deficit without generating a significant deviation from the estimate of the deficit by the end of the year. In the external sector, a current account deficit is expected around -1.7% of GDP for the current year. This context of solid macroeconomic fundamentals contributes to maintaining favorable conditions to accumulate international reserves and promote the relative stability of the exchange market.

The BCRD reaffirms its commitment to continue conducting monetary policy aimed at achieving its inflation target and maintaining macroeconomic stability, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to adopt the measures necessary for risks regarding price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting in November 2017, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.25% per annum.

The decision on the reference rate was adopted after an exhaustive analysis of the balance of risks around the inflation forecasts, the evolution of the main national macroeconomic indicators, the international environment relevant to the Dominican economy, market expectations and the medium-term predictions of that set of variables.

The monthly inflation rate for October was 0.0%, so that accumulated inflation at the tenth month of the year remained unchanged at 2.42%. Year-on-year inflation reached 3.48%, within the center of the target range of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0% established in the Monetary Program. Additionally, core inflation, related to monetary conditions, decreased to 2.23% year-on-year. Forecasts indicate that inflation would remain within the target range in the monetary policy horizon of 24 months.

In the external context, according to the Consensus Forecast, the outlook for the world economy remains favorable, projecting an expansion rate of around 3.1% in 2017 and 2018. Likewise, the International Monetary Fund, in its report World Economic Outlook (WEO) , for its acronym in English), projected an expansion of the global economy of 3.6% in 2017 and 3.7% in 2018. The greater dynamism in the world economy is the result of improvements in the growth of the advanced economies, while the Inflationary pressures remain contained. The United States of America (USA) would grow 2.2% in 2017 and 2.5% in 2018, a more optimistic scenario than the previous month, while the product of the Euro Zone (ZE) would expand by 2.2% and 1.9%, during those years. Inflation in these economies would remain relatively low, projecting 2.1% for the US in 2017 and 2018 and inflations of 1.5% and 1.3%, during the same period for the ZE.

Latin America continues to recover gradually and has emerged from the recession that hit it last year, with the exception of Venezuela. In that sense, the economy of the region would grow 1.7% in 2017 and 2.6% in 2018, according to Consensus Forecast. International prices of primary goods have tended to rise in recent months, mainly oil, while international financial conditions remain relatively favorable for emerging economies in the short term due to the abundant liquidity worldwide.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity was affected in September by the impact of the Irma and Mar<ed>a storms in sectors such as tourism and agriculture. However, preliminary figures show that in October there was an important recovery, as a result of the effects on domestic demand of the monetary easing measures taken in the month of July. It should be noted that the reduction in the MPR of 50 basis points, together with the reduction in the legal reserve of 2.2 percentage points in July, has had a large multiplier effect on credit to the private sector in national currency. Since these measures were adopted, private loans in national currency have grown by more than RD $ 41 billion, for an average of more than RD $ 10 billion per month, almost three times more than the average monthly growth of the first half of the year. In year-on-year terms, private credit in local currency grew around 11.0% year-on-year, in line with the rate of expansion of the Circulating Medium M1.

Regarding fiscal policy, the Government maintains its commitment to the deficit target of 2.3% of GDP established in the National Budget, while strengthening coordination between monetary and fiscal policies. On the other hand, the external sector shows a positive behavior, contributing to the increase in foreign exchange earnings and creating a favorable environment for the relative stability of the foreign exchange market and for the accumulation of international reserves.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target and to maintain macroeconomic stability, helping to create the conditions for the economy to grow around its potential. In that sense, it will continue to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to adopt the necessary measures against possible risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its November 2018 monetary policy meeting, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.50% per annum.

The decision to leave the reference rate unchanged is based on a detailed analysis of the balance of risks around inflation forecasts, including information from international and domestic macroeconomic indicators, market expectations and medium-term projections. Accumulated inflation as of October stood at 1.75%, while year-on-year inflation, from October 2017 to October 2018, reached 3.52%, remaining within the goal of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0% established in the Monetary Program.

On the other hand, core inflation, linked to monetary conditions, recorded a year-on-year change of 2.60% in October. The forecast system indicates that inflation would close below the lower limit of the target range in the current year, gradually converging to the midpoint of that range of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0% in the two-year monetary policy horizon.

In the external environment, the relevant economic outlook for the Dominican economy remains conditioned by the normalization of monetary policy in the United States of America (USA), the appreciation of the dollar in international markets and the increase in uncertainty in some emerging economies . On the other hand, during the last month, there has been a significant reduction in international oil prices associated with a moderation in geopolitical tensions among oil producing countries and the outlook for lower demand associated with the risk of a slowdown in world economy .

In this context, according to Consensus Forecast, the world economy would grow 3.2% in 2018 and 3.0% in 2019, driven by the US economy that would expand 2.9% and 2.7%, respectively, during those years. Given the dynamism shown by the US economy, the normalization process is expected to continue with an additional increase in the benchmark interest rate this year. On the other hand, the Euro Zone (ZE) is projected to grow 2.0% in 2018 and 1.7% in 2019, noting that the growth prospects of some of its main economies, such as Germany, Italy and Spain, have been revised downwards. Given that inflationary pressures remain moderate in these countries, the monetary policy stance of the European Central Bank would remain expansive in the medium term, which would contribute to increasing the interest rate differential with the US, contributing to maintain the appreciation of the dollar.
