Regarding emerging markets, a certain degree of uncertainty persists, with a slowdown observed in some economies with weak macroeconomic fundamentals. However, there are emerging economies that show significant dynamism, such as the cases of India and China whose economies would expand during 2018 by 7.3% and 6.6%, respectively. In the case of Latin America, the region is projected to grow 1.4% in 2018 and 2.0% in 2019, driven by the dynamism of economies in the region with solid foundations such as Chile, Peru, Colombia and the Dominican Republic. However, the growth projections of countries with economic vulnerabilities and socio-political tensions such as Venezuela, Argentina and Nicaragua continue to be corrected downwards.

Domestically, economic activity continues to grow above its potential, in a context of price stability. In effect, the real gross domestic product (GDP) expanded by 6.9% during the first nine months of 2018, driven mainly by investment and private consumption. According to the forecast system of the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic, economic activity would continue to be dynamic, closing the year 2018 with a growth of around 6.5%. On a consistent basis, monetary conditions remain favorable, characterized by an expansion of credit to the private sector in local currency close to 12% year-on-year at the end of November, while the growth rates of monetary aggregates are approaching the expansion of nominal GDP.

On the fiscal policy side, the moderation in public spending continues to be maintained at 5% year-on-year in October, while the expansion in revenues exceeds 12% year-on-year, contributing to the process of consolidating finances public. In the foreign sector, foreign exchange generating activities, such as tourism, remittances and exports, maintain a remarkable dynamism, with the current account deficit being slightly above 1.0% of GDP at the end of the year, associated with the highest oil prices. The good performance of the external sector has facilitated the accumulation of international reserves, allowing reserve coverage levels that exceed 4 months of imports and contributing to the relative stability of the exchange rate.

The proper management of monetary and fiscal policies have contributed to keeping inflation expectations of private agents anchored around the goal of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0%, while the country risk indicator of the Dominican Republic (EMBI) , for its acronym in English) remains significantly below the average risk perception for Latin America. In a changing international environment, the strength of the macroeconomic fundamentals of the Dominican Republic, accompanied by high economic growth and low inflation, give economic policies a greater capacity to react to any external shock that could put macroeconomic stability at risk.

In this sense, the monetary institution remains attentive to the evolution of the monetary policy normalization of the United States, as well as the dynamics of the dollar and the price of oil in the international market, being prepared to react in a timely manner to any factor that puts at risk the fulfillment of its inflation goal. The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
BCRD maintains its monetary policy rate at 4.50% per year

Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic. At its November 2019 monetary policy meeting, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 4.50% per annum.

The benchmark decision is based on detailed risk balance analysis for inflation forecasts, including international and domestic macroeconomic indicators, market expectations and medium-term projections. October's monthly inflation was 0.67%, while cumulative inflation in the first ten months of the year stood at 3.06%. On the other hand, year-on-year inflation, i.e. from October 2018 to October 2019, stood at 2.48%, remaining below the lower bound of the target range. Underlying inflation, reflecting monetary conditions, stood at 2.23% in October. For their part, both the inflation expectations of economic analysts and the BCRD forecasting system, indicate that inflation would be closer to the center of the target range of 4.0% to 1.0% at the end of 2019 and would remain around the core value of the target by 2020.

In the international environment, although the pockets of uncertainty that have been gravitating this year persist, some progress has been made in the negotiation process between the United States of America (USA) and China in the last month, which could lead to a potential trade agreement in the coming months. In this context, Consensus Forecasts maintains its moderate growth projection for the global economy of 2.5% in 2019, while the IMF forecasts a global expansion of 3.0% for this year.

Economic activity in the U.S. has gradually slowed, projecting growth to move from 2.9% in 2018 to 2.3% in 2019 and 1.8% by 2020, according to Consensus. In the face of weakening the economy and low inflation, the Fed has reduced its benchmark rate three times, accumulating a 75 basis point decline in the year. In addition, the Fed has been providing greater liquidity to the financial system through repurchase agreements (REPOS) and purchases of Treasury bills on the secondary market, with the goal of reducing short-term interest rates. Going forward, market analysts do not expect additional adjustments to the federal funds rate until at least mid-2020s.

As for the Euro Zone, the growth outlook remains low, rising at 1.1% and 1.0% for 2019 and 2020, respectively, conditioned by global trade disputes and uncertainty surrounding the UK's exit process from the European Union (Brexit). Considering the weak growth and lack of inflationary pressures, the European Central Bank continues to implement the recently announced package of expansionary measures, which include the liquidity provision programme for the private sector credit channeling and the purchase of sovereign bonds on the secondary market.

On the other hand, in Latin America (AL) uncertainty has been heightened as a result of socio-political conflicts that have arisen in different Latin American countries, further deteriorating the regional growth outlook to 0.4%, according to Consensus and 0.2% according to the IMF. The region's weak economic performance is conditioned by negative growth rates this year in countries such as Venezuela, Argentina, Nicaragua, Paraguay and Mexico, as well as by Brazil's modest expansion and the negative impact of social demonstrations in countries such as Chile, Bolivia and Colombia.

For raw materials, the average price of Texas intermediate oil (WTI) was around US$57 per barrel during the month of November, remaining below US$60 a barrel, a level as set out in the National Budget. On the other hand, the price of gold has remained at high levels, averaging US$1,475 per troy ounce in November, being used as a haven of value. This performance of oil and gold prices contributes to the continued favourable terms of trade of the Dominican Republic and benefit the external sector of the economy.

In the domestic context, preliminary information from the Monthly Economic Activity Index (IMAE) indicates that domestic demand continues to react favourably following the implementation of monetary easing measures. Indeed, the economy expanded by 5.2% year-on-year in October, having reached 5.1% in September. Thus, the average growth over the January-October period was 4.8%. The dynamism of economic activity in recent months would help economic growth be around its potential of 5.0% by the end of the year.

In particular, the expansionary monetary measures implemented since June, through the reduction by 100 basis points of the monetary policy rate and the release of more than RD$34 billion of legal lace resources to the productive sectors, have boosted private credit, which has increased by 11% so far this year and around 12% in the last twelve months. Monetary conditions will remain favourable over the coming months as monetary policy transmission mechanisms operate, boosting domestic demand through increased investment and private consumption.

On the other hand, the process of consolidation of public finances is maintained, with a primary surplus expected to be achieved at the end of 2019, as stipulated in the National Budget. In the external sector, foreign exchange-generating activities such as foreign direct investment and remittances continue to perform well, compensating for the recent moderation of tourism, which is expected to recover in the coming months. In this complex international environment, the Dominican Republic has maintained relative exchange rate stability, recording a cumulative depreciation of below the average of AL countries and emerging economies this year as a result of the strength of macroeconomic fundamentals and credibility in its economic policies.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to drive monetary policy towards achieving its inflation target and the smooth functioning of financial and payment systems, thus contributing to the maintenance of macroeconomic stability. In this sense, the institution will continue to monitor the moderation of the world economy and factors of uncertainty both externally and internally and its impact on aggregate demand, being prepared to continue to react in a timely manner to factors that may generate deviations from the inflation target and affect Dominican economic growth.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic, in its Monetary Policy Meeting of December 2012, decided to keep its Monetary Policy Interest Rate unchanged at 5.00% per annum. The Lombard Rate remains at 7.00% per annum.

In the month of November, the interannual rate of inflation was 3.37% and it is expected that by the end of 2012 it would be around 4.0%, below the lower limit of the Monetary Program target. The decision on the benchmark interest rate takes into account that inflation in 2013 would be within the target of 5% <U+00B1> 1%, according to the BCRD forecast models. Market expectations remain in line with the BCRD's inflation projection, while no significant deviations are discernible with respect to inflation in the monetary policy horizon, even considering the impact of the tax reform on domestic prices.

In the external context, the risks related to the fiscal situation of the industrialized countries remain high. The fiscal and debt crisis of the Euro Zone would cause the economy to remain in recession during 2013, with a fall in GDP of around 0.1%, according to analysts of the Economic Consensus. In the United States of America (USA), the inability to find a solution so far to the problem of the fiscal cliff (Fiscal Cliff, for its acronym in English) could generate new taxes and spending cuts of almost US $ 600 billion, affecting significantly the economic activity and with its sequel in the rest of the economies, especially in those that trade more closely with said nation. However, it is expected that some kind of agreement will soon be reached to solve this problem.

For 2013, US growth would be 1.9%, a reduction from the 2.2% expected for 2012. Given this situation of moderate growth, the Federal Reserve has announced that it would maintain an expansive monetary policy for the next three years, which means maintaining low interest rates until 2015. For emerging economies, growth prospects show positive signs in an environment where large changes in the prices of primary goods are not expected. Given this international scenario, the monetary policy of the BCRD would maintain a prudent stance as long as inflation remains in line with the objective and there are no significant deviations from the fiscal targets established in the 2013 Budget.

In the domestic sphere, the Gross Domestic Product projects a growth of around 4% by the end of 2012, still remaining below its potential capacity. For the year 2013, the macroeconomic framework contemplates a growth of 3.0% that could adjust positively if the behavior exhibited by private credit in the last five months is maintained. Indeed, after having contracted during all the months of the first semester of the year, starting in July, the credit in national currency of all financial institutions has grown by more than RD $ 30,000 million, in response to lower interest rates. If this behavior continues in 2013, there could be greater growth in private consumption and investment, with its consequent impact on domestic demand.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation in order to react timely to risks on price stability and good functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting in December 2013, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic decided to maintain the monetary policy rate at 6.25% per annum unchanged.

The decision regarding the leading rate takes into account inflation projections, as well as market expectations. The interannual inflation rate decreased for the third consecutive month, from its highest level of the year of 5.67% in the month of July, to 4.14% in November. Accumulated inflation to the eleventh month of 2013 was 3.49%, given the monthly variation of just 0.06%. Likewise, the interannual core inflation was reduced to 4.45%.

In the external context, the outlook for the world economy has improved, driven by the process of gradual recovery exhibited by the industrialized economies. Emerging economies continue to grow, although they show a slight deceleration with respect to the levels reached in recent years. The growth of the United States of America was revised upwards, standing at 2.0% in year-on-year terms and 4.1% in annualized quarterly terms. This growth has contributed to reduce unemployment to 7.0%, a decrease of more than one percentage point so far this year. On the other hand, macroeconomic indicators point to Europe coming out of recession. Inflationary pressures remain low in line with the behavior of commodity prices during the current year.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity and domestic demand show a dynamism of economic growth above 3.0%, projected in the macroeconomic framework for 2013. Credit to the private sector in national currency would be closing the year with a year-on-year growth greater than 13.5%, while improving prospects for activities related to foreign trade, mainly tourism, free zones and gold exports.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to take the necessary measures against possible risks to the stability of the economy. prices and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity and domestic demand show a dynamism of economic growth above 3.0%, projected in the macroeconomic framework for 2013. Credit to the private sector in national currency would be closing the year with a year-on-year growth greater than 13.5%, while improving prospects for activities related to foreign trade, mainly tourism, free zones and gold exports.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to take the necessary measures against possible risks to the stability of the economy. prices and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.

At its monetary policy meeting in December 2014, the Central Bank maintained its monetary policy interest rate (MPR) at 6.25% per annum, a neutral stance that contributed to higher growth without generating monetary inflationary pressures.

The decision on the benchmark interest rate was taken after an exhaustive analysis of the risk balance around the projections of inflation, growth and other macroeconomic indicators, as well as market expectations and the relevant international environment for the Dominican economy. Last November, accumulated inflation reached 2.30%, while the interannual rate stood at 2.68%, below the lower end of the target range of 4.5% <U+00B1> 1% for 2014. On the other hand, core inflation , related to the monetary conditions of the economy, was 3.14%. It is important to note that inflation continues to show a downward trend, driven by the continuous decline in the prices of primary goods in foreign markets, particularly oil. However, the forecasts indicate that inflation would return to the central point of the goal in the policy horizon.

In the international environment, the world economy would grow 2.6% in 2014 and 3.0% in 2015, according to the Consensus Forecast, driven largely by the United States of America (USA), whose growth in the third quarter of the year was revised upwards from 3.9% to 5.0%. Consumption and private investment continue to be the main determinants of the dynamism shown by the US economy, so it is expected that the expansion process in our main trading partner will continue to have a positive impact on Dominican growth. The US unemployment rate stood at 5.8% in December and the Federal Reserve (FED) expects it to be reduced to 5.25% by the end of next year, thus reaching its full employment level. Given this panorama, the FED would keep its monetary policy interest rate unchanged until the second half of 2015. Regarding the Eurozone (ZE), the growth of the third quarter was 0.8%, led by Greece (1.7%), Spain (1.6%), Germany (1.2%) and Portugal (1.1%). According to Consensus Forecast, for 2014 and 2015, growth in the ZE of 0.8% and 1.1%, respectively, would be expected. For Latin America (AL), Consensus Forecast projects a growth of only 0.9% this year, with a recession in Venezuela and Argentina, while Brazil grows around zero. The fall in LA is explained by the end of the so-called "Super Cycle of Commodities" that benefited the largest economies in the region.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity would end the year with a growth of around 7.0%, keeping close to its potential during 2015. The credit to the private sector in national currency that this year would register growth above 15%, would decrease gradually in 2015 to the range 10% -12%, rate around the growth of the nominal product expected for the coming year. In the external sector, the current account of the Balance of Payments would register a deficit of 3.5% of GDP in the current year, continuing its downward correction throughout 2015 to between 2.3% and 2.5% of GDP for the closing of the year. year. The favorable evolution of the external sector has contributed to maintaining stability in the foreign exchange market, closing the year with a year-on-year depreciation of around 3.5%. Additionally, it has facilitated the accumulation of gross international reserves (RIB), which will close the current year with a coverage of 3.1 months of imports. By 2015, the RIBs could exceed US $ 5,000 million, increasing import coverage to 3.2 months. The 2015 Budget contemplates a fiscal deficit of 2.4% of GDP, which is another indication of the solid foundations maintained by the Dominican economy.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to implement monetary policy aimed at achieving its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to take the necessary measures against risks to the stability of the economy. prices and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting for the month of December 2015, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.00% per annum.

The decision on the reference rate is based on a thorough analysis of the international and domestic environment, relevant to the Dominican economy, as well as the balance of risks around inflation forecasts and market expectations. It was observed that to the month of November, in accumulated terms, inflation reached 2.25%. Likewise, the interannual rate of inflation amounted to 1.54% that month. Additionally, core inflation, which reflects the monetary conditions of the economy, fell to 1.80% year-on-year. Inflation would end, at the end of the year, around the lower limit of the target established in the Monetary Program for 2015, gradually converging towards the center of the range of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0% in 2016.

In the external context, the Federal Reserve (FED) began the process of normalizing its monetary policy, with an increase of 25 basis points in its federal funds rate. According to the FED, this increase should not have harmful effects on the performance of the US economy, so the monetary institution maintains its growth prospects around its potential and inflation close to 2.0% in the medium term. The unemployment rate in the United States of America (USA) would remain around the level considered of full employment. A point to be highlighted is that the FED's decision would help to increase international interest rates and maintain the appreciation of the dollar in global capital markets.

Regarding the most recent economic projections of the Consensus Forecast (CFC), the growth of the world economy stands out at around 2.6% in 2015, improving to 2.8% in 2016. World growth would be led by the expansion of the industrialized countries , while the deceleration in emerging economies continues. In that sense, the US would register an expansion of 2.5% in both 2015 and 2016, while the Euro Zone (ZE) would continue consolidating its recovery with growth rates of 1.5% in 2015 and 1.7% in 2016. It is expected that Inflation tends to approach 2.0% in both the US and the ZE, while unemployment continues to fall.

On the other hand, the macroeconomic conditions of the emerging economies remain weak, while the outlook points to a slight improvement in 2016. In this line, Consensus Forecast estimates that Latin America would contract by 1.0% in 2015 and fall 0.1% in 2016. This result would be influenced by the evolution of Venezuela and Brazil, which would remain in recession until 2016, as well as by the moderation of growth in the net exporting economies of raw materials in the region. At the same time, in international markets, the fall in oil prices has worsened, which have already fallen to minimum levels since 2009, while the appreciation of the dollar continues.

Domestically, economic activity continues to grow above its potential. The most recent information from the Monthly Indicator of Economic Activity (IMAE) trend-cycle suggests that the economy is above the productive capacity of the economy, indicating that the current forecasts of the International Monetary Fund that contemplate a real GDP growth would be fulfilled in the range of 6.5% -7.0% for the close of this year. In the financial sector, private loans in national currency show double-digit growth, exceeding nominal product growth.

The external accounts of the economy continue to improve in an environment of low oil prices and good performance in revenues from tourism, remittances and exports from free zones. It is expected that by the end of 2015, the current account deficit will be around 2.0% of GDP, a situation that would remain for next year. With regard to fiscal policy, a primary surplus would be obtained in the current year that should be maintained next year, according to the 2016 Budget. These positive results in the external and fiscal accounts would facilitate the accumulation of reserves and the relative stability of the exchange market.

The Central Bank confirms its commitment to implement monetary policy aimed at achieving its inflation target, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to take the necessary measures against possible risks to stability of prices and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting for the month of December 2016, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate (MPR) at 5.50% per annum.

The decision on the reference rate was preceded by an exhaustive analysis of the national economic panorama, of the international environment relevant to the Dominican economy, and of market expectations regarding the main macroeconomic variables. Additionally, the balance of risks around the inflation projections was evaluated in order to prevent any deviation in the BCRD target. The latest data on inflation indicates that the interannual rate stood at 0.88% as of November, while the accumulated inflation rate reached 0.79% in the first eleven months of the year. Core interannual inflation, which reflects the monetary conditions of the economy, stood at 1.79 percent. By the end of the year, inflation would end well below the lower limit of the goal of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0%, contemplated in the Monetary Program.

In the external context, according to Consensus Forecast, the world economy would grow 2.5% in 2016, expecting an expansion of 2.8% for 2017 thanks to improvements in the growth projections of the United States of America (USA) and some emerging economies. In the case of the US, this year's growth would close around 1.6%, accelerating next year to 2.3%. On the other hand, real production in the Euro Zone (ZE) would grow 1.6% in 2016 and 1.4% in 2017. Inflation in these industrialized economies would remain positive, gradually approaching their respective targets. In that sense, inflation rates of 1.3% are expected for the US and 0.2% for the ZE in 2016. For next year 2017, inflation would rise to 2.4% in the US and 1.3% in the ZE. It should be noted that in the industrialized economies, labor market improvements would continue, with the US remaining in full employment and reaching a one-digit unemployment rate for the first time since the beginning of the 2007 financial crisis.

The perspectives of the emerging economies for 2017 indicate improvements in some of the larger economies such as Brazil and Russia. Both economies would be coming out of the recessions that affected them in 2016. China, on the other hand, would grow 6.6% in 2016 and 6.2% in 2017 according to the IMF, while India would have growth rates above 7.0% during these years. According to Consensus Forecast, Latin America would register a fall (-0.5%) in 2016, mainly due to significant contractions in economies such as Argentina (-2.3%), Brazil (-3.4%), Ecuador (-2.0%) and Venezuela (-10.7). %). There was also a slowdown in the growth of some commodity exporters such as Chile (1.6%), Colombia (2.0%) and Mexico (2.0%). For 2017, a recovery of growth in the region that would grow 1.8% is projected, driven by a better performance in Argentina (2.9%), Brazil (0.8%), Chile (2.1%), Colombia (2.5%) and Peru (4.2 %).

In the domestic sphere, economic activity evolves favorably in the short term. According to preliminary figures, the Monthly Indicator of Economic Activity (IMAE) would have grown around 6.4% in the January-November period, which would be the highest growth in Latin America for the third consecutive year. Credit to the private sector in national currency has expanded to around 12.0% to date, a rate consistent with the evolution of the Nominal Gross Domestic Product so far this year. With regard to fiscal policy, the rate of growth of public spending has slowed markedly in the second half of the year, indicating a more moderate fiscal policy, despite the reconstruction efforts in the areas of the country affected by the recent floods.

This fiscal effort, together with a current account deficit that would close the year between 1.7% and 1.9% of GDP, indicates that the Dominican economy remains healthy, exhibiting solid macroeconomic fundamentals, which creates favorable conditions for accumulating international reserves and promoting relative stability of the exchange market.

The Central Bank reaffirms its commitment to continue conducting monetary policy aimed at achieving its inflation target and maintaining macroeconomic stability, while continuing to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to adopt the necessary measures in the face of risks regarding price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting of December 2017, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to maintain its monetary policy interest rate at 5.25% per annum.

The decision on the reference rate was adopted after an exhaustive analysis of the balance of risks around the inflation forecasts, the evolution of the main national macroeconomic indicators, the international environment relevant to the Dominican economy, market expectations and the medium-term projections of this set of variables. Monthly inflation for November was 0.76%, causing accumulated inflation that month to reach 3.20%. Year-on-year inflation reached 4.14%, around the central value of the target range of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0% established in the Monetary Program. Additionally, core inflation, related to monetary conditions, stands at 2.31% year-on-year. Forecasts indicate that inflation would remain within the target range in the monetary policy horizon of 24 months.

In the external context, the world economy would close 2017 with a growth of 3.1% while the outlook for 2018 remains positive projecting an expansion rate of 3.2%, according to Consensus Forecast. The dynamism of the world economy in 2018 would be explained, to a large extent, by the behavior of the advanced economies. In this regard, growth forecasts for this group of countries have been revised upwards, projecting for the United States of America (USA), product expansions of 2.3% in 2017 and 2.5% in 2018, while for the Euro Zone ( ZE) growth would be 2.3% and 2.1%, during those years. Inflationary pressures in these economies would remain moderate, projecting 2.1% for the US in 2017 and 2018, while inflation in the EZ would be 1.5% and 1.4%, during the same period.

In Latin America the recovery is consolidated during 2017. With the exception of Venezuela, all the countries of the region would present positive growth. In that sense, the growth prospects, according to Consensus Forecast, point to an expansion of the Latin American economy of 1.8% by the end of 2017 and 2.6% in 2018.

International prices of primary goods have maintained an upward trend in recent months, while international financial conditions remain relatively favorable for emerging economies in the short term due to the abundant liquidity worldwide.

In the domestic sphere, economic activity has reacted very positively to the expansionary monetary measures implemented since August. Since then, credit to the private sector in national currency has increased around RD $ 55 billion, for year-on-year growth of more than 11.5%, which has contributed to the recovery of domestic demand. In effect, preliminary information from the Monthly Indicator of Economic Activity (IMAE) indicates an expansion of 6.8% during the month of November, reaching an accumulated growth of 4.2% during January-November of this year. Monetary conditions are expected to remain favorable, contributing to economic growth being around 4.5% at the end of 2017 and improving to 5.0% -5.5% by 2018.

Regarding public finances, the Central Government maintains the projection of a deficit of 2.3% of GDP established in the National Budget, in the context of a more active fiscal policy during the second half of the year. On the other hand, the external sector continues to show a positive performance, contributing to the increase in foreign exchange earnings and the strengthening of international reserves, in an environment of relative stability of the exchange rate.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target and to maintain macroeconomic stability, helping to create the conditions for the economy to grow around its potential. In that sense, it will continue to monitor the evolution of the world economy and the domestic situation, in order to adopt the necessary measures against possible risks on price stability and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems.
At its monetary policy meeting of December 2018, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 5.50% per annum.

The decision to leave the reference rate unchanged is based on a detailed analysis of the balance of risks around inflation forecasts, including information from international and domestic macroeconomic indicators, market expectations and medium-term projections. The monthly inflation for November was -0.35%, so the accumulated inflation during the first eleven months of the year was 1.39% and it is estimated with preliminary information in December that inflation would close the year at 1.3%. The forecast system indicates that inflation would gradually converge to the target range of 4.0% <U+00B1> 1.0% during the next year.

In the international environment, forecasts remain that the world economy would grow 3.2% during 2018 and moderate to 3.0% in 2019, according to Consensus Forecast. The global expansion of economic activity would continue to be driven by the United States of America (USA), which would grow 2.9% in 2018 and 2.6% in 2019. Given the continuing dynamism of the US economy and the conditions of full employment in the labor market , the Federal Reserve (FED) increased its benchmark interest rate by 25 basic points at its December meeting to a range of 2.25% - 2.50%. However, the FED said that by 2019 it expects a process of normalization of the monetary policy more gradual than initially expected, associated with lower inflationary prospects for next year.

On the other hand, Consensus continues to downgrade the growth prospects of the Euro Zone (ZE) for both 2018 and 2019, estimating expansions of 1.9% and 1.7%, respectively. This moderation in the ZE is influenced by the slowdown in some of its main economies, such as Germany, Italy and France. Given that the inflation forecasts for this group of countries remain below their target, the monetary policy stance of the European Central Bank would remain expansive in the medium term, which would contribute to increasing the interest rate differential with the US and to the strengthening of the US dollar in international markets.

In the case of Latin America, the region is projected to grow moderately by 1.4% during 2018 and 1.9% in 2019, driven by the dynamism of economies such as the Dominican Republic, Bolivia, Panama, Paraguay, Chile and Peru. However, the growth projections of countries with economic vulnerabilities and socio-political tensions such as Venezuela, Argentina and Nicaragua continue to be corrected downwards.

As for raw materials, there has been a significant reduction in the price of oil in recent months, leading to West Texas Intermediation (WTI) crude at levels close to US $ 45 per barrel. . This fall in the price of oil is associated with both supply and demand factors, especially the increase in oil production in economies that are not part of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) and the prospects for a moderation in global growth. However, according to the International Energy Agency, the reduction in the price of oil would be transitory, averaging in 2019 around US $ 55 per barrel.

Domestically, economic activity continues to grow above its potential, in a context of absence of inflationary pressures. In effect, according to preliminary estimates, the real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) would expand by 7.0% during 2018, driven mainly by investment and private consumption. Consistent with the economic dynamism, there is an expansion of credit to the private sector in national currency close to 11.0% year-on-year and a year-on-year growth of 11.2% in bills and coins issued, known as high-power money.

It is important to note that the weighted average passive interest rate of the multiple banks has increased by around 200 basis points after the increase of the Monetary Policy Rate of July 2018. This adjustment has allowed to close the interest rate differential with respect to to the US rates, helping to avoid any significant change in the investment portfolio in domestic and foreign currency that could put macroeconomic stability at risk.

On the fiscal policy side, the moderation of public sector expenditures with year-on-year growth of 5.2% was maintained as of November, while the expansion of revenues reached 13.2% year-on-year, contributing to the consolidation process of Public finances In the external sector, foreign exchange generating activities, such as tourism, remittances and exports, maintain a remarkable dynamism, with the current account deficit expected to be around 1.4% of GDP at the end of the year, associated with the higher oil prices. The good performance of the external sector has facilitated the accumulation of international reserves that exceed US $ 7,100 million, equivalent to a reserve coverage over the 4 months of imports and contributing to the relative stability of the exchange rate.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic is attentive to the evolution of the normalization of the monetary policy of the United States, as well as the dynamics of the dollar and the price of oil in the international market, being prepared to react in a timely manner to any factor that can generate inflationary deviations. In this sense, the issuing entity reaffirms its commitment to conduct monetary policy to achieve its inflation target and the proper functioning of the financial and payment systems, thus contributing to the maintenance of macroeconomic stability.
BCRD maintains its monetary policy rate at 4.50% per year

Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic. At its December 2019 monetary policy meeting, the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic (BCRD) decided to keep its monetary policy interest rate at 4.50% per annum.

The benchmark decision is based on detailed risk balance analysis for inflation forecasts, including international and domestic macroeconomic indicators, market expectations and medium-term projections. November's monthly inflation was 0.37%, while cumulative inflation stood at 3.45%. On the other hand, year-on-year inflation, i.e. from November 2018 to November 2019, stood at 3.23%, returning to the target range of 4.0% to 1.0%. Underlying inflation, reflecting monetary conditions, stood at 2.20% in November. For their part, both the inflation expectations of economic analysts and the BCRD forecasting system indicate that inflation would close 2019 below the target's core value and remain around 4.0% by 2020.

In the international environment, economic uncertainty has moderated slightly in recent months as the first phase of a trade agreement between the United States of America (USA) and China has been achieved, while there is greater clarity about the UK's exit from the European Union (Brexit). In that context, Consensus Forecasts, which brings together leading analyst firms that make international projections, maintains the forecast of moderate growth for the global economy of 2.5% for both 2019 and 2020, while the International Monetary Fund foresees an overall expansion of 3.0% for 2019 and 3.4% by 2020, according to the latest publication of the Economic Outlook in October.

Economic activity in the U.S. has gradually slowed, projecting growth to move from 2.9% in 2018 to 2.3% in 2019 and 1.8% by 2020, according to Consensus. In the face of weakening the economy and low inflation, the Fed has reduced its benchmark rate three times, accumulating a 75 basis point decline in the year. In addition, the Fed has been providing greater liquidity to the financial system through repurchase agreements (REPOS) and purchases of Treasury bills on the secondary market, with the goal of reducing short-term interest rates. Moving forward, the Fed and market analysts do not anticipate additional adjustments to the federal funding rate during 2020.

As for the Euro Area, the growth outlook remains low, rising at 1.2% and 1.0% for 2019 and 2020, respectively, conditioned by the weak performance of the industrial sector and the slowdown in international trade. Considering the absence of inflationary pressures, the European Central Bank continues to implement a package of expansive measures including the liquidity provision programme for the private sector credit channeling and the purchase of sovereign debt securities on the secondary market.

On the other hand, in Latin America, the deterioration of economic activity has been accentuated as a result of socio-political conflicts that have arisen in several of the countries of the region. Thus, growth prospects for Latin America remain low, with an expansion of 0.4% in 2019 and 1.4% in 2020. The region's economic slowdown is influenced by negative growth rates this year in Venezuela, Nicaragua, Argentina, Ecuador, Paraguay and Mexico, as well as the modest expansion of Brazil and the negative impact of social demonstrations in countries such as Chile, Bolivia and Colombia.

In terms of raw materials, global demand moderation contributed to the average price of Texas Intermediate Oil (WTI) being around US$57 per barrel during 2019, below the level set out in the $60 national budget per barrel. On the other hand, the price of gold has remained at high levels, averaging about $1,400 per troy ounce during 2019, being used as a haven of value in an environment of high uncertainty. This behaviour of oil and gold prices favors the Dominican Republic's terms of trade and benefits the external sector of the economy.

In the domestic context, the expansionary monetary measures implemented since June, through the cumulative reduction of 100 basis points in the monetary policy rate and the release of more than RD$34 billion of legal lace resources to the productive sectors, have contributed to the increase of private credit in national currency so far in the year. The dynamism of private credit in national currency is reflected in an expansion of more than 12% in year-on-year terms.

Favourable monetary conditions have boosted domestic demand through increased consumption and private investment. Economic activity has recovered by expanding year-on-year by 5.1% in September and 5.2% in October. In this context of dynamism in aggregate demand, economic growth is expected to be around its potential of 5.0% by the end of 2019 and during 2020.

In the domestic context, the expansionary monetary measures implemented since June, through the cumulative reduction of 100 basis points in the monetary policy rate and the release of more than RD$34 billion of legal lace resources to the productive sectors, have contributed to the increase of private credit in national currency so far in the year. The dynamism of private credit in national currency is reflected in an expansion of more than 12% in year-on-year terms.

Favourable monetary conditions have boosted domestic demand through increased consumption and private investment. Economic activity has recovered by expanding year-on-year by 5.1% in September and 5.2% in October. In this context of dynamism in aggregate demand, economic growth is expected to be around its potential of 5.0% by the end of 2019 and during 2020.

In the external sector, foreign exchange-generating activities such as foreign direct investment and remittances continue to perform well, compensating for the recent moderation of tourism, which is expected to recover in the coming months. In this complex international environment, the Dominican Republic has managed to strengthen its macroeconomic fundamentals, maintaining relative exchange rate stability and continuing the process of accumulation of International Reserves, which would end in 2019 at around US$8.5 billion, its highest historical level by year-end.

The Central Bank of the Dominican Republic reaffirms its commitment to drive monetary policy towards achieving its inflation target and the smooth functioning of financial and payment systems, thus contributing to the maintenance of macroeconomic stability. In this sense, the institution will continue to monitor the moderation of the world economy and factors of uncertainty both externally and internally and its impact on aggregate demand, being prepared to continue to react in a timely manner to factors that may generate deviations from the inflation target and affect Dominican economic growth.
